Order under Section 
Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
Citation: Duong v Gauthier, 2023 ONLTB 19375
Date: 2023-05-12 
File Number: LTB-L-076368-22(EAL-98421-21)
    In the matter of:         E, 426 Clarence Street
Ottawa Ontario K1N5R8
                       Between:                     Peter Duong                                                                                                  Landlord
                                      And
                                                  Than Robert Gauthier                                                                                     Tenant
  Your file has been moved to the Landlord and Tenant Board’s new case management system, the Tribunals Ontario Portal. Your new file number is LTB-L-076368-22
Peter Duong (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict Than Robert Gauthier (the 'Tenant') because:
•      the Tenant, another occupant of the rental unit or a person the Tenant permitted in the residential complex has seriously impaired the safety of any person and the act or omission occurred in the residential complex.
  This application was heard by videoconference on February 16, 2022 at 9 am.
  Only the Landlord attended the hearing.
  As of 10:26 am the Tenant was not present or represented at the hearing although properly served with notice of this hearing by the LTB. There was no record of a request to adjourn the hearing. As a result, the hearing proceeded with only the Landlord's evidence.
  Determinations: 
1.         As explained below, the Landlord has proven on a balance of probabilities the grounds for termination of the tenancy the application. Therefore, the tenancy is terminated as of May 23, 2023.
2.         The Tenant was in possession of the rental unit on the date the application was filed.
  File Number: LTB-L-076368-22
    3.         On October 15, 2021, the Landlord gave the Tenant an N7 notice of termination The notice alleges that the Tenant substantially interfered by threatening and harassing other tenants on multiple different dates. It also alleges the Tenant is the source of loud noise and racist language, as well as interrupting or interfering with other tenants’ sleep.  
  4.         The Landlord provided multiple letters from five other tenants that supported and documented threats and verbal and physical abuse to themselves and their pets. I accept this hearsay evidence, which went unchallenged, and find that:
-On October 15, 2021 the Tenant harassed, verbally abused and threatening to kill his housemate.
-On October 12, 2021 the Tenant harassed his neighbour and frightened him. 
-On October 11, the Tenant continued to make loud noises in his unit and disturbed other tenants in the residential complex. 
5.         I find that the Landlord has proved beyond the balance of probabilities that the Tenant impaired the safety of the Landlord and other tenants in the residential complex. 
6.         The Landlord incurred costs of $186.00 for filing the application and is entitled to reimbursement of those costs.
7.         There is no last month's rent deposit.
8.         I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would be unfair to grant relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act.
It is ordered that: 
1.      The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $186.00 for the cost of filing the application.
2.      The total amount the Tenant owes the Landlord is $186.00.
3.      If the Tenant does not pay the Landlord the full amount owing on or before May 23, 2023, the Tenant will start to owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from May 23, 2023 at 6.00% annually on the balance outstanding.
4.      The tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenant is terminated.  The Tenant must move out of the rental unit on or before May 23, 2023.  
5.      If the unit is not vacated on or before May 23, 2023, then starting May 24, 2023 the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
    File Number: LTB-L-076368-22
          6.   Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlord on or after May 23, 2023. The Sheriff is requested to expedite the enforcement of this order.

  1.        On August 25, 2021, the Landlord gave the Tenant an N5 notice of termination. The notice of termination contains the following allegations: The Tenant has piled garbage on the balcony leading to “horrific smells” and a “stink” that permeates through the entire residential complex and substantially interferes with the Landlord and other tenants’ rights in the residential complex. 
  File Number: LTB-L-076371-22(EAL-98422-21)

Date: 2023-01-10
File Number: LTB-L-073444-22
(EAL-98572-21)
    In the matter of:
422, 33 ONTARIO STREET KINGSTON ON K7L5E3
  Between:
Homestead Land Holdings Limited
Landlord
    and
    Virginia Larsson
Tenant
      Your file has been moved to the Landlord and Tenant Board’s new case management system, the Tribunals Ontario Portal. Your new file number is LTB-L-073444-22.
  Homestead Land Holdings Limited (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict Virginia Larsson (the 'Tenant') because the Tenant did not pay the rent that the Tenant owes.
  This application was heard by videoconference on October 26, 2022.
  The Landlord’s representative, Kimberly Adams, the Tenant, and the Tenant’s representative, John Done attended the hearing.
  Determinations:
  1.     The Tenant has not paid the total rent the Tenant was required to pay for the period from June 1, 2021 to October 31, 2022. Because of the arrears, the Landlord served a Notice of Termination effective August 6, 2021.
  2.     The Landlord collected a rent deposit of $1,427.66 from the Tenant and this deposit is still being held by the Landlord.
  3.     The Tenant paid $14,490.00 after the application was filed.
  4.     The Tenant’s representative took the position that the Landlord is holding a last month’s rent deposit that is greater than the current rent amount. The Landlord’s representative told the Board that the rent decreased as a result of cancelling the cost of storage and that represents the amount still being held by the Landlord. I find that this is not grounds

  to dismiss the Landlord’s application. The Tenant can seek to resolve this by filing her own application with the Board.
  5.     The Tenant’s representative also submitted that the N4 should be deemed invalid because it fails to set out the amount of rent due pursuant to subsection 59 (2) of the Act. He stated that the N4 misrepresents the rent which the Tenant paid during June and July 2021.
  6.     At the hearing the Tenant’s representative walked us through the ledger which represented the amount of rent charged, the amount of rent paid and the amount of rent due. While the Landlord may have allocated rent paid to previous arrears, the amount due on the N4 was in fact correct. Base of the information presented to me I find that the N4 served on the Tenant was valid.
  7.     The Tenant testified that she was impacted by the pandemic and as a result fell behind on her rent payments. She told the Board that she was receiving CERB for a period of time, however, she is now working and intends to pay the outstanding arrears.
  8.     In giving consideration to the Tenants circumstances, a delayed eviction would be appropriate. However, given the date this order is being issued, the Tenant has already had the benefit of additional time to seek financial assistance and/or alternative housing. Therefore, I find that a standard order is not unfair.
  9.     I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would be unfair to grant relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act.
  It is ordered that:
  1.     Unless the Tenant voids the order as set out below, the tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenant is terminated. The Tenant must move out of the rental unit on or before January 21, 2023.
  2.     The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $7,546.31*, which represents the amount of rent owing and compensation up to January 10, 2023, less the rent deposit and interest the Landlord owes on the rent deposit.
  3.     The Tenant shall also pay to the Landlord $45.64 per day for compensation for the use of the unit starting January 11, 2023 to the date the Tenant moves out of the unit.
  4.     The Tenant shall also pay to the Landlord $186.00 for the cost of filing the application.
  5.     If the Tenant does not pay the Landlord the full amount owing* on or before January 21, 2023, the Tenant will start to owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from January 22, 2023 at 5.00% annually on the balance outstanding.

  6.     If the unit is not vacated on or before January 21, 2023, then starting January 22, 2023, the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
  7.     Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlord, on or after January 22, 2023.
  8.     If, on or before January 21, 2023, the Tenant pays the amount of $9,352.70** to the Landlord or to the Board in trust, this order for eviction will be void. This means that the tenancy would not be terminated, and the Tenant could remain in the unit. If this payment is not made in full and on time, the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
  9.     The Tenant may make a motion to the Board under subsection 74(11) of the Act to set aside this order if they pay the amount required under that subsection on or after January 22, 2023 but before the Sheriff gives vacant possession to the Landlord. The Tenant is only entitled to make this motion once during the period of the tenancy agreement with the Landlord.
      January 10, 2023 Date Issued

2022canlii75097:
Order under Section 21.2 of the
Statutory Powers Procedure Act
and the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
  File Number: EAL-95828-21-RV
    In the matter of:      C, 149 HOLITMAN DRIVE
NEPEAN ON K2J1P6
  Between:                  Michal Seman                                                                                               Landlord
    and
 
Christine Middleton Glenn Sheasgreen

Tenants

    Review Order
    Michal Seman (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict Glenn Sheasgreen and Christine Middleton (the 'Tenants') because the Landlord requires possession of the rental unit for the purpose of residential occupation. The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenants remained in the unit after the termination date.
  This application was resolved by order EAL-95828-21 issued on November 23, 2021. On December 23, 20221, the Landlord requested a review of the order.
On March 4, 2022, the Board heard the Landlord’s request for review. On this date, only the Landlord attend the hearing. The Tenants did not attend and were not represented.
  On May 10, 2022, the Board issued order EAL-95828-21-RV granting the Landlord’s request for review and their L2 application.
  On June 8, 2022, the Tenants filed a request to review the order EAL-95828-21-RV alleging they were not reasonably able to participate in the hearing and that the order contains serious error.
  A preliminary review of the review request was completed without a hearing.
  Determinations:
  Were the Tenants reasonably able to participate in the hearing?
  1.        In the request, the Tenants submit that they did not attend the hearing because they were told by Tenant Duty Counsel that they did not have to attend. The Tenants submit that

  Tenant Duty Counsel told them this because the Landlord’s application was for eviction and the Tenants had already vacated the rental unit.
  2.        The Tenants’ submissions clearly indicate that they were aware of the Board hearing, and they chose not to attend. The Tenants claim they did not attend the hearing because of legal advice they received, despite indicating in their request to review that they had issues they wanted addressed at the hearing. The fact the Tenants may not have received good legal advice with respect to their attendance at the hearing is not an error in the order or in the Board’s proceeding. Neither is it a reason for not being reasonably able to participate in the hearing.
  3.        Based on the submissions in the request, I am satisfied the Tenants were reasonably able to participate in the hearing. I say this because the Tenants confirm knowing about the hearing and did not attend. In my view, this demonstrates a lack of due diligence on the part of the Tenants. A lack of exercising due diligence is not a reason for which a request to review an order would be granted. My findings are in keeping with the guidance of the Court in Q Res IV Operating GP Inc. v. Berezovs’ka, 2017 ONSC 5541 CanLII (Div. Ct.) paragraph 8 which states:
  If parties are not diligent in dealing with legal proceedings then they cannot demand that a Tribunal waste its resources by rehearing matters a second time. To allow this would undermine the ability of the administration of justice to deliver timely, cost-effective and final orders.
  4.        Based on the above, the Tenants are not entitled to have the Landlord’s application re- heard because they failed to exercise due diligence. Therefore, the request to review based on the Tenants’ allegation that they were not reasonably able to participate in the hearing, is denied.
  Is there a serious error in the order or in the Board’s proceeding?
  5.        In the request, the Tenants make submissions in support of their position with respect to the Landlord’s application. The Tenants allege the Member made their decision based on misleading evidence and lies submitted by the Landlord. The Tenants further alleged that the Landlord never paid them compensation equal to one month’s rent as required for having served them an N12 Notice of Termination (‘N12 notice’).
  6.        I have reviewed the Board’s record and the order. In doing so, I note that in the Landlord’s evidence package there is supporting documentation that compensation was paid to the Tenants with respect to the N12 notice. If the Tenants wanted to challenge the Landlord’s evidence on this point, then the Tenants should have attended the hearing to give their evidence on the issue.
  7.        With respect to the Tenants submitting the Landlord mislead or lied to the Board, the opportunity for the Tenants to challenge the veracity of the Landlord’s evidence was at the hearing and not in a request to review the order.

  8.        A request to review is not an opportunity for a party to re-litigate or reargue their position in hopes of a more favorable outcome. Nor is it an opportunity to present evidence and submissions that could and should have been presented at the hearing.
  9.        In the request to review, the Tenants do not identify any serious error in the order or in the Board’s proceeding. Given my finding, the Tenants’ request to review the order, on the grounds of serious error in the order or in the Board’s proceeding, is denied.
  It is ordered that:
  1.        The request to review order EAL-95828-21-RV issued on May 10, 2022, is denied. The order is confirmed and remains unchanged.
    June 14, 2022
Date Issued                                                                     Dawn Wickett
Member, Landlord and Tenant Board

255 Albert Street, 4th Floor Ottawa ON K1P6A9

Order under Section 69
Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
  File Number: EAL-97264-21
    In the matter of:
807, 550 LANG'S ROAD OTTAWA ON K1K4C2
  Between:
Centurion Property Associates Inc.
Landlord
    and
    Sarah Gillis
Tenant
      Centurion Property Associates Inc. (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict Sarah Gillis (the 'Tenant') because:
  a)     The Tenant, another occupant of the rental unit or someone the Tenant permitted in the residential complex has wilfully or negligently caused undue damage to the premises, failed to properly prepare the rental unit on several occasions for pest control treatments, and substantially interfered with the Landlords’ and other Tenants’ reasonable enjoyment of the premises (the ‘L2/N5 application’).
  b)     The Tenant or another occupant of the rental unit has committed an illegal act or has carried out, or permitted someone to carry out an illegal trade, business or occupation in the rental unit or the residential complex involving the production of an illegal drug, the trafficking in an illegal drug or the possession of an illegal drug for the purposes of
trafficking (the ‘L2/N6 application’).
  c)      The Landlord also applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenant because the Tenant, another occupant of the rental unit or a person the Tenant permitted in the residential complex has seriously impaired the safety of any person (the L2/N7 application’). The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenant remained in the unit after the termination date.
  This application was heard via video conference on November 24, 2021.
  Only the Landlord’s representative, Anne Skelly, attended the hearing. The Landlord’s witness Deanna Blackwood and HomePro pest control contractor Keith Kekam attended. As of 10:23 a.m. the Tenant was not present or represented although properly served with a notice of hearing by the Board.

        Determinations:
  L2 application: substantial interference, illegal act, and serious impairment of safety
  1.     The residential complex is an apartment building.
  2.     The Landlords served a Notice to End Your Tenancy for Interfering With others, Damage, or Overcrowding (‘N5 notice’) and a Notice to End Your Tenancy for Illegal Acts (‘N6 notice’) on the Tenant on August 03, 2021 by handling the documents to an adult person in the unit.
  3.     The Landlords served a Notice to End your Tenancy for Causing Serious Problems in the Rental Unit or Residential Complex (‘N7 notice’) on the Tenant on August 03, 2021 by handling the documents to an adult person in the unit.
  Evidence pertaining to the allegations in the N5 and N6:
  4.     The N5 notice alleged that the Tenant substantially interfered with the Landlords’ reasonable enjoyment of the premises. The N6 notice alleged that the Tenant engaged in illegal acts on the premises. The grounds for the N5 and N6 notices together with evidence adduced at the hearing included:
  •         Excessive noise from Tenant’s guests, yelling and banging on the evening of July 08, 2021 and July 16, 2021.
  •         On June 23, 2020 a unit inspection found damages to the parquet flooring, missing bathroom door, kitchen doors, and broken vanity door.
  •         On April 14, 2020, a photograph evidence of the lobby showed the Tenant removing a delivered parcel which was later reported as stolen as it belongs to another tenant
  •         On July 8, 2021 a crack pipe was found outside Tenant’s unit door, bag found outside the apartment door in the building hallway containing drug paraphernalia. The Police was called, and the bag was secured with a police report completed accordingly
  5.     K.K., a HomePro Pest Control technician, testified at the hearing as a witness for the Landlord. K.K testified that on May 13, 2021 and June 18, 2021, he attended the complex to treat the unit for cockroaches. K.K testified that he was unable to treat the unit due to extreme sanitation issues.
  6.     K.K testified that the unit was infested with cockroaches due to extreme sanitation issues. He testified that the unit was poorly managed with clothes and injection needles on floor.

  As a result of the state of the unit, pest control treatments could not be carried out on that day. The photographic evidence is entirely consistent with K.K testimony.
  7.     The N5 notice gave the Tenant an opportunity to void the notice by ceasing all her conducts complained of in the notice in the seven days after the notice was served; so, the voiding period was from August 26 to September 01, 2021.
  8.     The N7 notice alleged that the Tenant seriously impaired the safety of another person and substantially interfered with the Landlords’ reasonable enjoyment of the premises. The grounds for the N7 notice along with evidence adduced at the hearing included:
  •         All of the grounds set out in the N5 and N6 notices.
•         On July 17, 2021 Tenant’s guest harassed tenant for not allowing them to gain access to the building.
•         Tenant approached tenant on July 18, 2021 for not letting her guests into the building
Legislation and Analysis:
  The L2/N5 Application - Tenant has Substantially Interfered with the Landlord
  9.     The N5 notice was served pursuant to sections 62 and 64 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (‘the Act’). Section 62 sets out that a landlord can give a notice of termination if the tenant, another occupant of the rental unit or a guest of the tenant wilfully or negligently causes undue damage to the rental unit.
  10.  Section 64 sets out that a landlord can give a notice of termination if the conduct of the tenant is such that it substantially interferes with the reasonable enjoyment of the residential complex for all usual purposes by the landlord or another tenant or substantially interferes with another lawful right, privilege or interest of the landlord or another tenant.
  11.  The Tenant has an obligation under section 33 of the Act to maintain the rental unit in a state of “ordinary cleanliness”.
  12.  I accept the uncontested testimony of the Landlord’s witness Deanna Blackwood and find that the Landlord proved, on a balance of probabilities, that the Tenant has substantially
interfered with the Landlord’s lawful rights, privileges and interests by failing to maintain the rental unit in a state of ordinary cleanliness, such that the Landlord’s was unable to perform necessary pest control treatments.
  13.  I am satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that the Tenant did not void the substantial interference claim or the damages claim set out in the N5 notice. The state of the Tenant’s unit showed little or no improvement when the Landlord re-inspected it on September 01, 2021, the last day of the void period and to date the unit is not in a state of ordinary cleanliness. Therefore, the Landlord was entitled to file the L2 application for eviction of the Tenant.

      14.  Regarding Tenant’s alleged stealing delivered package from the lobby, yelling, and harassing tenant for denying her guest building entrance, there was no evidence establishing that the alleged acts seriously impaired the safety of any person.
  15.  Re File No. TSL-19235-11, 2011 LNONLTB 2109 (Ont. L.T.B.) illustrates the strict requirement under Section 66 of the Act. In that matter, the Board held that threats made to a security guard did not constitute serious impairment of safety. In paragraph 12, the Board stated: “Verbal harassment and threats alone rarely constitute a serious impairment of safety to another person”.
  16.  In Re File No. SWL-35940 [2002] O.R.H.T.D. No. 146 (O.R.H.T.), the Board held the
tenant’s actions, i.e., swearing at the landlord and acting inappropriately, while they made the landlord afraid, did not constitute serious impairment of safety. The adjudicator stated that any impairment of safety must be serious, and the Act was not intended to legislate good manners.
  17.  In File No. SWL-01073, [1998] OR.H.T.D. No. 18, the Tribunal held that while many of the other tenant felt intimidated by the tenant, there was no objective evidence that anyone’s safety was in real jeopardy. The Tribunal held that subjective fear was insufficient.
  18.  In this case here, the Landlord asserted that on July 17 and 18, 2021, the Tenant swore at Tenants when they denied her guests access into the building. As illustrated in the abovementioned cases, the Tenant’s actions on these dates do not “constitute serious impairment of other Tenants’ safety”.
  19.  The Landlord did not meet the burden of proof. I am not satisfied that the Tenant seriously impaired the safety of another person or that they wilfully caused undue damage to the residential complex.
  The L2/N6 Application
  20.  Section 61(1) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act') provides as follows:
  61 (1) A landlord may give a tenant notice of termination of the tenancy if the tenant or another occupant of the rental unit commits an illegal act or carries on an illegal trade, business or occupation or permits a person to do so in the rental unit or the residential complex.
  21.  The Board’s Interpretation Guideline 9 states that while the term illegal is not defined in the Act, it would include a serious violation of a federal, provincial or municipal law. This guideline also states that an illegal act will be serious if it has the potential to affect the character of the premises or to disturb the reasonable enjoyment of other tenant (Samuel Property Management Ltd. v. Nicholson 2002 CanLII 45065 (ON CA), 2002 61 O.R. (3d) 470 C.A. at para. 28)
  22.  The Landlord’s representative testified that the Tenant engaged in illegal acts on the premises as drug paraphernalia and needles were found in her unit, a crack pipe was

  found outside of the unit door, and a bag of drug paraphernalia was also found outside the unit door. This was supported by photographic and documentary evidence.
  23.  Despite these assertions, the Landlord’s representative did not lead any satisfactory evidence to establish that the alleged illegal acts by the Tenant was for the purpose of trafficking contrary to section 61 of the RTA. Drug paraphernalia may be indicative of drug use, it does not automatically lead to a finding that Tenant or someone living with the Tenant has committed an illegal act or is carrying on an illegal business at the residential complex.
  The L2/N7 Application - Serious Impairment of Safety
  24.  Section 66 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the “Act”), establishes the “impairment of safety” ground for termination. That provision states:
  A landlord may give a tenant notice of termination of the tenancy if,
  (a)   An act or omission of the tenant, another occupant of the rental unit or a person permitted in the residential complex by the tenant seriously impairs or has seriously impaired the safety of any person; and
  (b)   The act or omission occurs in the residential complex.
  25.  Based on the Landlord’s evidence, I am not satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the behaviour of Tenant meets the elements of section 66 of the Act.
  Damage
  26.  Subsection 89(1) of the Act gives the Board the authority to award a landlord damages. It provides as follows
  “A landlord may apply to the Board for an order requiring a tenant to pay reasonable costs that the landlord has incurred or will incur for the repair of or, where repairing is not reasonable, the replacement of damaged property, if the tenant, another occupant of the rental unit or a person whom the tenant permits in the residential complex wilfully or negligently causes undue damage to the rental unit or the residential complex and the tenant is in possession of the rental unit”.
  27.  The Landlord relied upon an assessment provided by a contractor. He suggested to the Landlord the following:
  •         Install the missing Hardwood floors at the cost of $2,320.
•         Replace the Bathroom door at the cost of $225.00
•         Replace missing Kitchen and vanity doors at $780.00
•         Patch and Paint bathroom Ceiling at the cost of $600.00

  28.  The photographs taken by the Landlord and submitted into evidence show missing wood to the hardwood floors, bathroom door, kitchen and vanity door, and bathroom ceiling.
  29.  Given all these factors concerning the condition of the unit, I find that the evidence of the professional assessment of damages to the parquet flooring, missing bathroom door, kitchen doors, windows, and broken vanity door can be reasonably repaired and replaced at the cost of $4,435.25 (Total cost of work $3925.00 + HST of $510.25).
  Section 83 Considerations
  30.  The Board must determine whether, notwithstanding the breaches of the Act, it would be unfair in all the circumstances to grant relief from eviction.
  31.  The Landlord requested a standard 11-day order terminating the tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenant, and evicting the Tenant, due to the extent of the damage caused to the rental unit and because the Tenant substantially interfered with the Landlord’s rights, privileges and interests. The Landlord testified that she is unaware of any circumstances of the Tenant that would cause me to delay or deny eviction of the Tenant.
  32.  The Tenant did not attend the hearing to provide evidence regarding their circumstances and therefore there is no evidence before the Board for consideration.
  33.  I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance
with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would be unfair to grant relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act as the Tenant did not attend the hearing and there were no circumstances before me that would suggest that termination was unfair in this case.
It is ordered that:
  1.     The tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenant is terminated, as of March 20, 2022. The Tenant must move out of the rental unit on or before March 20, 2022.
  2.     The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $4,435.25, which represents the contractor’s estimated amount of cost to repair damages to the hardwood floors, bathroom door, kitchen and vanity door, and bathroom ceiling on or before March 20, 2022
  3.     The Tenant shall also pay to the Landlord $186.00 for the cost of filing the application.
  4.     If the Tenant does not pay the Landlord the full amount owing on or before March 20, 2022, the Tenant will start to owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from March 21, 2022, at 2.00% annually on the balance outstanding.

  5.     If the unit is not vacated on or before March 20, 2022, then starting March 21, 2022, the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
  6.     Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlord on or after March 21, 2022.

Determinations:
  1.     The Landlord served the Tenants a Notice of Termination (N8 Notice) because the Tenants were persistently late in paying their rent.
  2.     The N8 Notice served upon the Tenants by the Landlord lacks sufficient detail as required by subsection 43(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006.
  3.     The Ontario Divisional Court in Ball v. Metro Capital Property and Lockhurst (December 19, 2002), Toronto Docket No. 8/02, found that subsection 43(2) of the Act requires that a notice served upon a tenant must include dates and times of the Tenants’ breaches of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the ‘Act’).
  4.     The N8 Notice served upon the Tenants does not include the dates when the Tenants allegedly paid their rent late.
  5.     Therefore, the N8 Notice served upon the Tenants is defective, and the Board cannot consider the Landlord’s application to terminate the tenancy on the basis that the Tenants were persistently late in paying their rent.

Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
  File Number: EAL-92738-20
    In the matter of:
313, 1375 KENSINGTON PARKWAY BROCKVILLE ON K6V6L5
  Between:
Kensington Manor
Landlord
    and
    Kandy Kirkey
Tenant
    Kensington Manor (the 'Landlord') applied for an order requiring Kandy Kirkey (the 'Tenant') to pay compensation for the damages caused by the Tenant or a person the Tenant permitted in the residential complex.
  This application was heard by video conference on December 21, 2021. At 1:48 pm, the Landlord’s Representative Joey Kay attended the hearing.
  Determinations and Reasons:
  1.     The Tenant was still in possession of the rental unit as of the date the application was filed.
  2.     The rental unit is a one-bedroom apartment in a multi-unit complex.
  3.     On the date of the hearing, the Landlord’s Representative confirmed that vacant possession had been returned to the Landlord on November 30, 2020.
  4.     The Landlord’s L2 application was filed November 24, 2020 under section 89(1) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006, (the ‘Act’) claiming for compensation for damages in the amount of $3 899.31 for the following items: flooring, baseboards, kitchen countertops, towel rack and shampooing carpets all of which were discovered during a pre-move out inspection on our around November 5, 2020.
  5.     Pursuant to s.89 of the Act,
  (1) A landlord may apply to the Board for an order requiring a tenant or former tenant to pay reasonable costs that the landlord has incurred or will incur for the repair of or, where repairing is not reasonable, the replacement of damaged property if,

  (a) while the tenant or former tenant is or was in possession of the rental unit, the tenant or former tenant, another occupant of the rental unit or a person permitted in the residential complex by the tenant or former tenant wilfully or negligently causes or caused undue damage to the rental unit or the residential complex;
  6.     In order for an application for compensation for damages made pursuant to subsection 89
  (1)   of the Act to succeed, a landlord must establish the following:
a)  There was property damage to the rental unit or residential complex;
b)  The damage is “undue” meaning that it is not normal wear and tear and it is not insignificant; and
c)  The damage was a result of wilful or negligent conduct by the Tenant, occupant or guest.
  7.     If all of these factors are met, then the Board can award the Landlord’s the reasonable cost of repair, or the replacement cost if it is not reasonable for the damage to be repaired.
  8.     Not all types of damage that may occur in a rental unit or residential complex will meet the test or requirement of section 89 of the Act.
  9.     Some damage may not have any element of wilfulness or negligence and a landlord, as the property owner, will have to bear the cost of repairing that damage.
  10.  Section 89 is clear and a plain language reading of the section establishes that the Tenant must have wilfully or negligently caused the damage.
  11.  The Landlord’s Representative said the Tenant was provided with a copy of the L2 application and details of the charge back. Submitted into evidence was an email dated November 9, 2020 where the Landlord writes to the Tenant about an exit inspection prior to the termination of tenancy and noting “quite a bit of damage incurred inside of the unit that is not the result of wear and tear. Rather it is the result of the wilful negligent conduct of yourself and or/your guest.” A reply to the email from the Tenant to the Landlord on November 12, 2020 states “I will speak to my Ontario works worker.”
  12.  The Landlord’s Representative reviewed sections 25 and 26 of the Lease as they pertain to the Tenant’s obligation to maintain the unit in a good state of repair. Section J pertains to the Tenant(s) and/or guest(s) responsibility not to damage the unit wilfully or negligently. This was provided to the Tenant as per the November 9, 2020 email in paragraph 9. A copy of the Lease was submitted as evidence.
  13.  The Landlord’s Representative reviewed the before and after photos taken prior to tenancy and post tenancy as submitted into evidence.

  14.  The Landlord’s Representative argued that the Tenant, as a pre-condition to tenancy, signed an Incoming/Outgoing Residents Inspection Report on or about April 3, 2019. Submitted into evidence was a copy of the report and photos of the rental unit prior to the Tenant moving in. Also submitted into evidence was a list of the charge back costs should damage occur.
  15.  In the L2 application, the Landlord is seeking $3899.31 as the cost to repair or replace the damaged property.
  16.  On the date of the hearing, the Landlord’s Representative, upon review of the evidence, requested to amend the application to include; the application filing fee, cost to replace the countertop and the cost to repair/replace the baseboard and flooring and painting. As detailed below, the revised total is significantly less than what was filed with the L2 application.
  Kitchen Countertop
  17.  The Landlord’s Representative said that the counter tops had cut marks throughout the kitchen and that it was necessary to replace them at a cost of $300.00. Submitted as evidence was the Home Depot Invoice with a total cost for the countertop of $172.00. The Landlord believes it is reasonable for the Tenant to compensation the Landlord for the total cost of the countertop.
  18.  Based on the evidence before me, I find that it is reasonable that the Tenant compensate the Landlord in the amount of $172.00 for the cost to replace the damaged counter tops. I find it is more likely than not that it was a result of negligence on the part of the Tenant that resulted in the damage to the countertop.
  Flooring and Baseboards
  19.  It was the position of the Landlord that the Tenant caused damage to the laminate flooring in the living room and dinning room and is seeking $2865.27 for replacement costs. The Landlord claims that the floors need to be replaced due to scratches and that all the floors need to be replaced for consistency throughout the rental unit. Additionally, the baseboards were damaged, possibly caused by the Tenant’s rabbit, scratching and chewing and relieving itself in the unit. Before and after photos of the flooring and baseboards were submitted into evidence. The Landlord is seeking $650.00 for the area damaged to the flooring and baseboards for which the Tenant is responsible.
  20.  Based on the uncontested evidence before me, I find the damage to the laminate flooring and baseboards to be undue property damage not a result of normal wear-an-tear. By allowing the Tenant’s pet to relieve itself and scratch the flooring and baseboards in the

  rental unit causing damage to the floor and baseboards, the Tenant has exhibited negligent conduct.
  21.  Furthermore, I find that the quote of $650.00 to replace the flooring and baseboards for that section of the room where there is damage to be reasonable and this amount shall be awarded.
  Paint
  22.  The Landlord is seeking $297.08 for the cost of paint to repair the baseboards. The Sherwin-Williams invoice was submitted as evidence. When I questioned the Landlord’s Representative on the cost of the baseboard paint, based on my experience, she suggested 25% of the total invoice as a reasonable cost to the Tenant. Accordingly, I find
$74.27 to be a reasonable cost for paint to repair the area of baseboard damaged as a result of the Tenant’s negligence.
  23.  Based on the uncontested evidence before me, I am satisfied that the damages to the rental unit as described in paragraphs 17 to 22 is a result of the Tenant’s wilful and/or negligent conduct. I say this based on the photographs presented by the Landlord that suggest damage beyond normal wear-and-tear. The Landlord’s claim will be granted.
  24.  This order contains all of the reasons for the decision within it. No further reasons shall be issued.
It is ordered that:
  1.     The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $896.27, which represents the reasonable costs of repairing the damage to the large section of flooring, baseboards and countertop.
  2.     The Tenant shall also pay to the Landlord $186.00 for the cost of filing the application.
  3.     The total amount owing under this order is $1082.27.
  4.     If the Tenant does not pay the Landlord the full amount owing on or before March 31, 2022, the Tenant will start to owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from April 1, 2022 at 2.00% annually on the balance outstanding.

Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
  File Number: EAL-87949-19
  In the matter of:
xxx
  Between:

  and
    HM
Tenant
    RB and JB (the 'Landlords') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict HM (the 'Tenant') because the Tenant did not pay the rent that the Tenant owes (L1 application).
  The Landlords applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenant because the Tenant has been persistently late in paying the Tenant's rent. The Landlord also applied for an order for the Tenant to compensate the Landlords for undue damage to the rental unit (L2 application).
  This application was heard via video conference on June 23, 2021. Only the Landlords attended the hearing.
At 9:23 a.m. the Tenant was not present or represented at the hearing.
  Determinations:
  L1 application:
  1.     The Tenant has not paid the total rent the Tenant was required to pay for the period from December 1, 2019 to February 14, 2020. Because of the arrears, the Landlords served a Notice of Termination effective December 16, 2019.
  2.     The Tenant vacated the rental unit on February 14, 2020. The Tenant was in possession of the rental unit on the date the application was filed.
  3.     The monthly rent was $1,175.00.
  4.     The Tenant made no payments towards the rent after the application was filed.
  5.     At the hearing, the Landlords acknowledged that there were clerical errors on the L1 update form submitted to the Board. Specifically, that new rent came due for January 1,

  2020 and February 1, 2020 and not 2021. In addition, the filing fee cost was $190.00 and not $186.00.
  6.     The Landlords collected a rent deposit of $1,175.00 from the Tenant and this deposit is still being held by the Landlords.
  7.     Interest on the rent deposit is owing to the Tenant for the period from November 4, 2018 to December 16, 2019.
  L2 application: Form N8 – Persistent Late Payment of Rent
  8.     The Tenant vacated the unit. As a result, the hearing of the application to terminate the tenancy for persistent late payment of rent, is moot.
  9.     At the hearing, the Landlords requested the consent of the Board to withdraw their application.
  10.  In accordance with subsection 200(4) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), I consent to the withdrawal of the application.
  L2 application: Damages
  11.  The Landlord’s L2 application for damages was amended to increase the compensation sought from $372.90 to $429.40. The amendment was granted as the Landlords provided the amended application to the Tenant prior to the hearing.
  12.  The issue to be determined by the Board is whether the Tenant has wilfully or negligently caused undue damage to the rental unit.
  13.  The residential property is a two-storey house, with two bedrooms. The Tenant rented the entire house.
  14.  The Landlords testified that the Tenant caused undue damage to a bedroom window. The Landlords stated that they were told by the Tenant that the Tenant’s son was playing ball in the bedroom and broke the window’s glass pane.
  15.  The Landlords submitted into evidence photographs taken of the broken glass window.
  16.  The Landlords testified that the window’s glass could no be replaced, rather they had to replace the entire window, as it was less expensive to do so.
  17.  The Landlords purchased and installed the new window. The Landlords claims the cost of the window was $380.00, plus $49.40 tax, for the total of $429.40.
  18.  To be successful on a claim for damages the Landlords must prove on a balance of probabilities that the damage claimed is “undue”. There is no definition in the Act of “undue”, but it is fair to say that it means “out of the ordinary” or “not wear and tear caused by ordinary usage.” The Landlords must also establish that the Tenant, wilfully or

  negligently caused the damage. If the Landlords establishes undue damage which was caused wilfully or negligently then the Landlords must lead sufficient evidence to show what the reasonable cost to repair or replace.
  19.  Based on the uncontested before me, I find on a balance of probabilities that the Tenant, or an occupant of the unit, wilfully or negligently caused undue damage to the rental unit. The Tenant’s son caused the window’s glass to break when he was playing with a ball in the bedroom.
  20.  I find that the Landlords incurred the costs of $429.40 to replace the entire window and this is a reasonable cost.
  It is ordered that:
  1.     The tenancy between the Landlords and the Tenant is terminated as of February 14, 2020, the date the Tenant gave vacant possession of the rental unit to the Landlords.
  2.     The Tenant shall pay to the Landlords $1,737.26*, which represents the amount of rent owing and compensation up to February 14, 2020, less the rent deposit and interest the Landlords owe on the rent deposit.
  3.     The Tenant shall pay to the Landlords the amount of $429.40, which represents the reasonable cost incurred of replacing the damaged property.
  4.     The Tenant shall also pay to the Landlords $190.00 for the cost of filing the application.

The Landlord has also applied for an order requiring the Tenant to compensate the Landlord for the damage. The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenant remained in the unit after the termination date. 
  A.D. (the 'Tenant') applied for an order determining that D.A. (the 'Landlord') harassed, obstructed, coerced, threatened or interfered with him; entered the rental unit illegally; and substantially interfered with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit or residential complex by the Tenant.  The Tenant also applied for an order determining that the Landlord had breached her maintenance responsibilities.
  These applications were heard in Peterborough on November 2, 2010.
  The Landlord and the Tenant, with his legal representative, L.C., attended the hearing.
    Preliminary Issues:
  The Tenant vacated the rental unit approximately September 30, 2010; therefore, the Landlord was no longer seeking an order to evict the Tenant.  However, the Landlord had discovered additional damage to the rental unit after she filed the L2 application with the Board.  At the hearing, she was seeking over $1,000.00 in damages to the rental unit, plus lost rental income for the month of October 2010.  With the consent of the Tenant, the application was amended to hear evidence about the additional claim by the Landlord for damages.
  With respect to the N7 Notice, the Tenant’s legal representative submitted that the notice was defective because it lacked sufficient detail.  She cited the Ball vs Metro Capital case.  The Landlord did not make a submission regarding the sufficiency of the notice itself.  She relied upon the conversations which she had with the Tenant, and correspondence which she sent to the Board, but she had not sent a copy to the Tenant.  I ruled that the N7 Notice had sufficient detail about the alleged damage to the door; however, that part of the notice regarding the alleged alcohol abuse was vague in that it lacked details and dates of alleged incidents.  Therefore, evidence and testimony was heard about the alleged damages only. 
        Determinations – Landlord’s Application:
  1.        The Tenant caused undue damage to the rental unit by damaging the entrance door.  He attempted to repair the door; however, the repair job was not acceptable to the Landlord; therefore, she had the door replaced.
2.        Based on the evidence presented at the hearing, the Landlord has not met the burden of proof, on a balance of probabilities, regarding the alleged substantial interference with her lawful right, privilege or interest; therefore, this part of the Landlord’s application is dismissed.
  Determinations – Tenant’s Applications:
1.         The Landlord has breached her maintenance responsibilities under section 20 of the Act by not maintaining the rental unit so that it is free of moisture build-up, resulting in mildew and mould growth.
2.         The Landlord entered the rental unit illegally, on or about September 21, 2010, when she entered the rental unit to take photographs of the unit, without advising the Tenant of the true purpose of the entry.
3.         The Landlord has substantially interfered with the Tenant’s reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit by breaching his privacy, and by refusing to correct the moisture problem, as advised by the Public Health Unit.
4.         The Landlord has harassed the Tenant by requiring him to pay his rent before it is due.
    It is ordered that:
  1.        The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $323.70, which represents the reasonable costs of replacing the damaged door.
2.        The Tenant shall also pay $170.00 to the Landlord for the cost of filing the Landlord’s application.
3.        The Landlord shall pay $45.00 to the Tenant for the cost of filing the Tenant’s applications.
4.        The Landlord shall also pay a lump sum rent abatement of $147.00 for breaching her maintenance responsibilities.
5.        The Landlord shall also pay a lump sum rent abatement of $245.00 for substantially interfering with the Tenant’s reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit, harassing and obstructing the Tenant, and illegally entering the rental unit.
6.        The amount owing by the Landlord to the Tenant shall be offset against the amount owing by the Tenant to the Landlord.  The Tenant owes $56.70 to the Landlord.
7.        If the Tenant does not pay the Landlord the full amount owing on or before November 30, 2010, he will start to owe interest.  This will be simple interest calculated from December 1, 2010 at 2.00% annually on the balance outstanding.

  REASONS
   
Reasons to Order EAL-09252-10 issued on November 10, 2010 by Lynn Neil.
  D.A. (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict A.D.M. (the 'Tenant') because he, another occupant of the rental unit or someone he permitted in the residential complex has wilfully or negligently caused undue damage to the premises, and because he or someone he permitted in the rental unit or residential complex has substantially interfered with the reasonable enjoyment or lawful right, privilege or interest of the Landlord in a residential complex which has three or fewer residential units. The Landlord has also applied for an order requiring the Tenant to compensate the Landlord for the damage.  The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenant remained in the unit after the termination date.
  A.D. (the 'Tenant') applied for an order determining that D.A. (the 'Landlord') harassed, obstructed, coerced, threatened or interfered with him; entered the rental unit illegally; and substantially interfered with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit or residential complex by the Tenant.  The Tenant also applied for an order determining that the Landlord had breached her maintenance responsibilities.
  These applications were heard in Peterborough on November 2, 2010.
  The Landlord and the Tenant, with his legal representative, L.C, attended the hearing.
    Preliminary Issues:`
  The Tenant vacated the rental unit approximately September 30, 2010; therefore, the Landlord was no longer seeking an order to evict the Tenant.  However, the Landlord had discovered additional damage to the rental unit after she filed the L2 application with the Board.  At the hearing, she was seeking over $1,000.00 in damages to the rental unit, plus lost rental income for the month of October 2010.  With the consent of the Tenant, the application was amended to hear evidence about the additional claim by the Landlord for damages.
  With respect to the N7 Notice, the Tenant’s legal representative submitted that the notice was defective because it lacked sufficient detail.  She cited the Ball vs Metro Capital case.  The Landlord did not make a submission regarding the sufficiency of the notice itself.  She relied upon the conversations which she had with the Tenant, and correspondence which she sent to the Board, but she had not sent a copy to the Tenant.  I ruled that the N7 Notice had sufficient detail about the alleged damage to the door; however, that part of the notice regarding the alleged alcohol abuse was vague in that it lacked details and dates of alleged incidents.  Therefore, evidence and testimony was heard about the alleged damages only. 
      Reasons:
  The Landlord testified that three times in June 2010 the Tenant left his window open.  She claimed to have closed it three times from the outside.  On July 21, 2010 she did an inspection of the rental unit and noticed mould on top of the vinyl flooring and in the grooves.  She took a pail of Javex and removed the mould from the flooring.  She also claimed that the carpeting was damaged by mould and urine.
  The Landlord introduced into evidence two undated and unsigned letters from allegedly previous tenants (Exhibits #2 and #3) to support her claim that previous tenants had no issues with the rental unit.  Exhibit #3 appears to have been part of a larger letter, from which one paragraph has been photocopied.  Since the authors of these letters were not present to be directly examined or cross examined, I have placed very little weight on these documents.
  The Tenant claimed that the mould in the rental unit was due to improper air ventilation and circulation in the basement rental unit.  He denied that his leaving the window open had caused the moisture build-up and mould.  Moreover, he submitted that he needed some fresh air circulating in the rental unit.  The Landlord had not provided him with a dehumidifier as she had done for the previous tenant.  The Tenant attached to his application some photos showing that the outside window frame was damaged – there was paint peeling off the frame.  He also introduced into evidence a photo of the wall below the window in his rental unit, and there was no damage evident inside the rental unit.  He testified that the mould started to appear on the floor, away from the wall – not at the wall as the Landlord had stated.  He also stated that there was mould underneath the carpeting which had been laid directly on the concrete.  He also stated – and supported his testimony with photographic evidence – that there was mould in front of the kitchen cabinets, along the baseboard around the rental unit, and around the exterior and seams of the shower unit.  He stated that he first noticed mould shortly after moving into the rental unit, and he notified the Landlord on July 13, 2010.  He believes that there were refrigerator issues which account for some of the mould problem in the kitchen.  The Landlord cleaned the area around the refrigerator, and she also replaced the full sized refrigerator with a bar sized fridge.
  The Peterborough Public Health Unit inspected the rental unit on August 16, 2010 (see Exhibit #4) and stated that the vinyl flooring and carpeting should not have been laid directly on the concrete.  The Landlord stated that she spoke with the inspector after receiving the letter, and the inspector supposedly gave her different advice from what is contained in the letter; however, the Landlord had no evidence to corroborate this claim.
  Based on the evidence presented at the hearing, I find on a balance of probabilities that the Tenant has not caused the mould damage, as claimed by the Landlord.  There were a number of contributing factors, including the laying of the carpet and vinyl directly on the concrete floor, and inadequate air ventilation in the rental unit which is located below grade, in the basement.  Therefore, this part of the Landlord’s application is dismissed including the Landlord’s claim for lost rental income.
  The Tenant claimed in his T6 application that he had told the Landlord about the mould problem but she had failed to correct the problem.  Based on the evidence presented at the hearing, I find on a balance of probabilities that the Landlord has breached her maintenance responsibilities under section 20 of the Act.  Therefore, I am awarding a rent abatement of 10% for the period July to September 2010.  Moreover, the Landlord has substantially interfered with the Tenant’s reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit by accusing him of causing the problem, rather than finding the true source of the problem and addressing it properly.
  The Tenant acknowledged that he damaged the entrance door on August 19, 2010 when he tried to no avail to unlock the door.  He than broke down the door in order to gain access to his rental unit.  He advised the Landlord by letter dated August 19, 2010 of the damage he had done.  The Tenant tried to repair the door, by buying a door and hiring a handyman to install the replacement door.  The Landlord was not satisfied, however, with the repair job.  She stated that the Tenant replaced the broken door with a used one that did not fit properly, and that damage was also done to the door frame. She introduced into evidence some photos which show that the repair job was probably inadequate as she claimed.  Although she observed the repair job in progress, she did not advise the Tenant that the finished work was not acceptable until about a week later.  The Landlord then purchased a new door ($261.54), and had it installed.  The new door needs to be painted, at an estimated cost for labour of $100.00.  This estimate seems excessively high, considering that her son will paint the door.  I am, therefore, allowing only $50.00 for labour, plus the cost of the door and paint, and the cost of two keys ($12.16), for a total damages award of $323.70.
  With respect to the illegal entries, the Tenant stated that the Landlord told him that she had entered his rental unit once in June 2010 to close the window while he was away.  The Landlord denied this allegation at the hearing.  On September 21, 2010 approximately the Landlord entered the rental unit to take photographs.  She did not tell the Tenant the true reason for her entry when she gave him a handwritten note on September 20, 2010.  She only stated that she would be taking someone through to see the unit, which was available for rent, because the Tenant had given notice of his intention to terminate the tenancy October 1, 2010.  The notice provided by the Landlord on September 20, 2010 was not an adequate notice, because it provided false information about the reason for the entry; therefore, I find on a balance of probabilities that the Landlord has illegally entered the rental unit.
  The Landlord collected the rent before the due date throughout the whole tenancy.  On April 21, 2010 she collected the rent for May 2010.  On May 19, 2010 she collected the rent for the months of June and July 2010.  On July 31, 2010 she collected the rent for August 2010.  She stated that she wanted the rent pre-paid because the Tenant was not working at the time.  However, the Landlord does not have the authority under the Act to require pre-payment of rent under any circumstances.
  In addition the Landlord called the police, and sent the police to the home of the Tenant’s mother.  The police were not sure why they had been called.  No charges were laid or warnings issued by the police.
  I find on a balance of probabilities that the Landlord has harassed the Tenant by requiring him to pre-pay the rent, and by calling the police to complain about the Tenant without a legitimate cause.
  The Landlord on numerous occasions called the mother of the Tenant when she had issues with the Tenant.  The Tenant introduced into evidence a handwritten list of dates when the Landlord had called his mother.  This list (Exhibit #1) was written by the Tenant’s mother.  The Landlord did not deny having called the Tenant’s mother on numerous occasions.   Based on the evidence presented at the hearing, I find on a balance of probabilities that the Landlord has substantially interfered with the Tenant’s reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit.  She has breached his privacy by discussing issues in the tenancy with another person, without the explicit permission of the Tenant.
  The Landlord also obstructed the Tenant by failing to provide an information package to the Tenant, as required by section 11 of the Act.
  I am awarding a rent abatement of 10% for each month of the tenancy, because the Landlord has repeatedly breached the rights of the Tenant throughout the whole tenancy.  This rent abatement amounts to $245.00.
  The Tenant had documentary evidence to support most of his testimony.  I have placed a medium weight on his testimony and evidence.  The Landlord, however, had very little documentary evidence or witnesses to corroborate her claims, with the exception of the damage to the door, for which the Tenant had readily admitted responsibility.  The Landlord did not seem to understand her responsibilities and rights under the Act, nor those of the Tenant.  She rationalized her actions (for example, calling the Tenant’s mother about issues, entering the rental unit without proper notice of her intent to take photographs, collect the rent in advance, etc) and did not seem to understand or care that she had contravened the governing legislation.  She had no evidence to corroborate her testimony on some significant issues; for example, she claimed that when she spoke with the inspector of the Public Health Unit, the inspector told her information different from that contained in the letter of August 16, 2010.  I did not find the Landlord to be a credible witness, and I have placed a low weight on her testimony.
  It should be noted that the Landlord has re-rented this rental unit to new tenants, but she has not replaced the flooring as directed by the Public Health Unit.  This should have been done before the new tenants moved in.  The Landlord should immediately take the necessary corrective action to ensure that this rental unit meets all health, safety and maintenance standards.   Proper flooring needs to be correctly installed.  Also the problem with the air moisture level must be investigated and corrected.

The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenants remained in the unit after the termination date.
  This application was heard in Brockville on April 26, 2010.
  The Landlord’s Director, [Landlord Director’s name removed] and the Landlord’s Representative, [Landlord Representative’s name removed] attended the hearing.
  As a preliminary matter, the Landlord’s Director testified that on April 18, 2010, the two Tenants told him that they were not attending the hearing on April 26, 2010 and that they would find a way to delay the process. The Landlord’s Representative also mentioned that on December 22, 2009 the Tenants did not attend the Landlord’s application for rental arrears and eviction and that on February 19, 2010 the Tenants did not attend their own request to review the Order emanating for the December 22, 2009 hearing.
  I notified the Landlord’s representative and the Landlord of my obligation under subsection 83(2)
of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the ‘Act’) and asked whether there was any information to provide concerning why the eviction should be delayed or refused.  The Landlord’s representative and the Landlord only provided information on the reasons why the Tenants should not be given any relief from eviction and did not provide any such information as to any reasons or circumstances why the Tenants should be granted relief from eviction.
      Determinations:
  1.   The Landlord collected a rent deposit of $800.00 from the Tenants and this deposit is still being held by the Landlord.

    2.   Interest on the rent deposit is owing to the Tenants for the period from July 1, 2009 to
April 8, 2010.
  3.   The Tenants did not correct the problem within the time period set out in the Notice of
Termination.
  4.   On June 30, 2009 the Tenants signed a lease agreement.
  5.   Section 9 of the lease agreement states that the Tenants shall pay for the water.
  6.   Section 11 of the lease agreement states that the Tenants “ shall enter into an agreement with the appropriate utility supplier prior to taking possession of the premises,…..and to be responsible o this authority for all charges in relation to the supply of said utilities until the last day of the tenancy….”
  7.   Based on the Landlord’s numerous invoices and letters from the Town of Gananogue there is no doubt that since July 1, 2009 to March 30, 2010 the Tenants did not enter into an agreement with the Town of Gananoque to pay the water for the rental unit.
  8.   Because of the water account is still under the Landlord’s name and the Town of Gananoque is threatening to cut off the water supply to the rental unit the Landlord’s Director paid the outstanding amount of $1,342.29 in April 2010.
  9.   Stanbar Properties v. Rooke (September 22, 2005) (Ont. Div. Ct), the court found that the tenant’s refusal to comply with the condition to maintain property insurance constituted substantial interference with the landlord’s lawful rights obtained under the lease agreement.
  10. I find that the Tenants in this case are refusing to comply with the condition to enter in an agreement for the water supply with the Town of Gananoque, which is not prohibited by the RTA and the parties agreed to in the lease, have substantially interfered with the Landlord’s lawful rights and privileges.
  11. The Tenants have been aware of their responsibility to enter in an agreement for the water supplier since June 30, 2010 and they still have not acted even though the Tenants are aware that the water supply may be shut off by the Town of Gananoque and the hardship it is causing the Landlord.
  12.  I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would be unfair to grant relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act.
        It is ordered that:

2010  to the date the Tenants  move out of the unit; and $170.00 for the cost of filing the application.

  Determinations:
  1.        I find that the Landlord did not and does not have the genuine intention to move into the Tenant’s rental unit.
2.        The Landlord failed to pay $71.49 to the Tenant for the interest on last month's deposit of $700.00 collected on April 1, 2006,as required by the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act').
3.        The Tenant moved into the rental unit on April 1, 2006.  The Tenant has been paying rent of $700.00 including heat and hydro until January 2010.
4.        I find that the Landlord unilaterally and illegally raised the Tenant’s rent from February 2010 by having the Tenant pay hydro in excess of the agreed monthly rent of $700.00.
5.        The Landlord collected rent in excess of the amount of $1,035.99 allowed by the Act .
6.        I find that the Tenant withheld $700.00 for the November 2010 rent.
7.        I find that the Landlord owes the Tenant $452.48.  This amount represents $1,035.99 for the illegal rent for the payment of hydro from February 1, 2010 to October 18, 2010 and $71.49 for the interest on the last month rent deposit until December 31, 2010  and $45.00 for the cost of filling the Tenant’s application less $700.00 that the Tenant withheld for the November 2010 rent.
It is ordered that:
  1.        The Tenant’s November 2010 rent is offset by part of the Landlord’s illegal rent increase.
2.        The Landlord shall pay the Tenant $452.00. 
3.        The amount of $452.00 shall be offset against the Tenant’s December 2010 rent of $700.00.
4.        The Tenant shall deduct the amount of the hydro bill from her rent from October 19, 2010 until the Landlord has changed the hydro bill to his name.
5.        The Landlord shall change hydro bill for the Tenant’s rental unit to his name on or before December 31, 2010.
6.        The Tenant shall return to the Landlord on or before December 15, 2010, a post dated cheque from the Landlord for the amount of $80.23.

  REASONS
         
Reasons to Order EAL-11078-10 and EAT-11639-10 issued on December 3, 2010 by Gerald Naud.
  GB (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict SM (the 'Tenant') because the Landlord wants to move into the rental unit. (EAL-11078-10)
  And
  SM (the 'Tenant') applied for an order determining that GB (the 'Landlord') has collected or retained money illegally by: a) not paying the Tenant the interest owing on the last month rent deposit: b) charging the Tenant illegal rent.  (EAT-11639-10)
  These applications were heard in Pembroke on November 19, 2010.
  The Landlord, the Tenant and the Tenant’s Representative, AS attended the hearing.
  REASONS:
  The Tenant has been residing in one of the rental units of a two (2) unit residential complex since April 1, 2006.  The Tenant has been paying a monthly rent of $700.00 including hydro and heat until the end of January 2010. In the early part of 2010, the Landlord had the smart meters installed for the two rental units and asked the tenants of the two (2) rental units to pay the rent plus the hydro.  There was no notice of rent increase.
  In early October 2010, the Tenant made the Landlord aware that he owed her the interest on her last month rent deposit and that she disagreed and opposed the payments of hydro.  On October 23, 2010, the Landlord served a notice of eviction to the Tenant because he wanted to move into the rental unit on January 1, 2011 with a post dated cheque for December 31, 2010, for the amount of $80.23, for the interest on the last month rent deposit.  On October 25, 2010, the Landlord filed an application with the Board. 
  Did the Landlord have the genuine intention to move into the rental unit at the time the Landlord served on the Tenant a notice of eviction?
  In his affidavit filed with the Board the Landlord states “for the personal use and enjoyment for myself and my wife and children.”
  At the hearing, the Landlord testified that moving in the Tenant’s rental unit is necessary to stabilize or improve his financial situation.  He also testified that the house that he presently resides in and owns with his spouse was never for sale or for rent.
  The Landlord’s testimony is contradictory.  I fail to understand how the Landlord’s financial situation will improve if he is to live in the Tenant’s rental unit and not sell or rent his other home.
  Secondly, in early October 2010, the Tenant invoked her right to stop paying an illegal charge and on October 23, 2010 the Landlord replies with a notice of eviction..  Meanwhile, there is no dispute that the other tenant living in second rental unit is still paying the hydro bill since February 2010 without opposing the Landlord.  I find it more believable that the Landlord’s application was brought forward because the Tenant has attempted to secure and enforce her legal rights.
  For these reasons, I find on the balance of probability that the Landlord did not have the genuine intention to move into the Tenant’s rental unit at the time the Landlord served on the Tenant the notice of termination (October 23, 2010) and the application(October 25, 2010).
  Although, the Landlord claims that since the notice of eviction and the application has been served on the Tenant, he is now engaged in a trial separation.  This new element was not corroborated by any document or witness.  The Tenant should not be subjected to the Landlord’s attempts at a separation.  I did turn my mind to this new element but it does not change my final decision.
  Pursuant to section 204 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006, I have ordered the conditions on the Landlord because they are necessary to reinstate the parties to their original contractual lease obligations and to provide closure to the issues.

FAS (the 'Tenant') applied for an order determining that AD & YD (the 'Landlords') harassed, obstructed, coerced, threatened or interfered with him, entered the rental unit illegally and substantially interfered with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit or residential complex by the Tenant or by a member of his household. The Tenant also applied for an order determining that the Landlords have not repaired or maintained the rental unit or the residential complex and have not complied with health, safety, housing or maintenance standards.
  The Landlords have also applied for an order terminating the tenancy and evicting the Tenant and for collection of monies for wilful or negligent damage in the rental unit or in the residential complex. 
  These applications were heard together, in Ottawa, on December 9, 2010.
  The Tenant, and the Landlords, attended the hearing.
  The Tenant complains that there are several cracks in the cement floor of the garage. He goes further stating that this may cause the entire garage to collapse, and because it is attached to the house itself, it may cause the house to also collapse. There was no evidence that this is cause for any concern at all. This appears to be a common occurrence in most garages in the area in question. There was an inspection done of the property and there was no such concern about the garage or the attached house, by the inspectors.
  The Tenant also complains that the fence in the backyard dividing the properties is going to fall and seriously injure someone or even cause the death of someone. A small part of the fence in question, which belongs to the neighbours and is beginning to lean a little, is certainly not in such bad shape as to cause any concern about actually falling down or of causing any safety concerns.
  The Tenant also failed to produce any relevant evidence that would convince the Board that the Landlord’s illegally entered the rental unit or caused any serious interference with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit by the Tenant or by his family.
  With respect to the Landlord’s application, they were requesting that the tenancy be terminated and were also requesting payment of monies for damages in the rental unit. The damages were for cleaning (professionally) deep stains on the carpet on the stairway, and for priming and repainting the bedrooms, for a container of sealant for the driveway because the Tenant appears to have had a leaky radiator which stained the driveway. I find that these ‘damages’ are as the result of normal wear and tear in the rental unit. This is a 4 or 5 year tenancy, and the Tenant has already given proper notice to terminate the tenancy and return to Saudi Arabia, on or before December 31, 2010. The Tenant has undertaken to have the stairs cleaned with a professional steam cleaning machine and he has already cleaned all of the walls in the bedrooms, including any crayon/pencil marks on the closet doors or walls.

LTG (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict MA (the 'Tenant') because he or another occupant of the rental unit has committed an illegal act or has carried out, or permitted someone to carry out an illegal trade, business or occupation in the rental unit or the residential complex involving the production of an illegal drug, the trafficking in an illegal drug or the possession of an illegal drug for the purposes of trafficking.
  This application was heard in Ottawa on December 2, 2010.
  The Landlord’s representative, AS, and the Tenant, attended the hearing. The Landlord’s representative had summonsed one witness, RM, of the Ottawa Police Services, who attended and was the only witness. 
  The Landlord’s Agent called only one witness RM to support her application for termination in this case. RM is a detective with the Ottawa Police Services, and has been with the OPS for some thirteen years, seven of those years working in the drug unit. He was the lead officer in the execution of a search warrant in the Tenant’s rental unit where the Tenant has resided for about three years. The residential premises is an eight story apartment building with 117 rental units housing a variety of tenants, be they seniors, families or other individuals, both single and married. 
  This witness verbally laid out a detailed account of the raid by police and the items discovered and seized as a result. During this raid the police found, in pill bottles, 12 tablets of Oxycontin, 80 tablets of oxycontin on the Tenant’s person, 98 tablets of methyl morphene, and at least 24 other tablets of oxycontin, as well as various amounts of ectasy and recindal, 2 digital scales, 2 cell phones, pepper spray and a fire arm holster. As well the Tenant had no less than 141 different other illegal substances. The Police Officer testified that all of the illegal drugs were found in the rental unit or on the Tenant’s person.
The witness also testified that as a result of these findings the Tenant was arrested and charged with six (6) separate offences under the relevant legislation.
  The Tenant’s defence consisted of an explanation that all of those drugs, including the ones found on his person belonged to a friend and were all received with a Doctor’s prescription. The tenant did not submit any evidence that would or could corroborate that defence. This application must be successful, and the Landlord’s representative has requested that the termination be as soon as possible and be expedited by the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff). I concurred with the Landlord and set a date of termination to be December 14, 2010.     
          Determinations:
  1.        The Tenant has committed an illegal act involving the production of an illegal drug, trafficking in an illegal drug as well as possession of an illegal drug for the purposes of trafficking in the rental unit and the residential complex.
2.        I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would be unfair to grant relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act.
      It is ordered that:
  1.        The tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenant is terminated.  The Tenant must move out of the rental unit on or before December 14, 2010.
2.        If the unit is not vacated on or before December 14, 2010, then starting December 15, 2010, the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
3.        Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlord on or after December 15, 2010. The Sheriff is requested to expedite the enforcement of this order.

  The Landlord’s application is not for rent arrears. What the Landlord is calling rental arrears are actually new and separate charges for air conditioning over a period of time.
