PHL (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict AP (the 'Tenant') because the Landlord requires the rental unit for his own use as residential purposes. The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenant remained in the unit after the termination date.
  This application was heard in Ottawa on January 5, 2011.
  The Landlord, and the Tenant, and the Tenant’s representative, MG, attended the hearing.
  There were two issues that had to be determined in a preliminary kind of way. The first was that the Landlord was a corporation. Convention had it, at one time, that a notice for Landlord’s own occupation could not be given by a corporate Landlord. At issue here is whether there could be an exception for closely held corporations, given that section 202 of the Act states that in “...making findings on an application, the Board shall ascertain the real substance of all transactions and activities.” Divisional Court has now come down in favour of allowing a corporation to give notice in some circumstances.
  On an appeal from the LTB, the Court stated:
  Whether a sole shareholder can require possession of a rental property owned by a corporation for own use should be determined on a case-by-case basis. The consideration of this matter should include the nature of the shareholding and the discretion granted in section 202 of the Landlord and Tenant Act.
  In the case at hand here there are two brothers who have formed a small holding company and who have each consented to the request. Both own equal shares of the company.
  The Landlord’s application to evict the Tenant is also found to have been made in ‘good faith’ in this instance.
  The second issue was whether or not the Board was prepared to grant section 83 relief if the evidence was clear that it should do so.
  With respect to this issue the Board is always prepared to consider all the circumstances in determining the award of relief to Landlords or Tenants, and especially in the case of the termination of a tenancy.   
  Determinations:
  1.        The Landlord’s application is made in ‘good faith’, and a properly filed affidavit was included in the request.
2.        I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would not be unfair to postpone the eviction until March 31, 2011, pursuant to subsection 83(1)(b) of the Act.
It is ordered that:
  1.        The tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenant is terminated.  The Tenant must move out of the rental unit on or before March 31, 2011.
2.        If the Tenant does not move out of the unit on or before March 31, 2011 he shall pay to the Landlord $27.95 per day for compensation for the use of the unit from March 1, 2011 to the date he moves out of the unit.
3.        If the unit is not vacated on or before March 31, 2011, then starting April 1, 2011, the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
4.        Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlord on or after April 1, 2011.

  This application was heard in Ottawa on January 11, 2011.
  The Landlord’s representative, KR and the Tenants attended the hearing.
  I notified the Parties of my obligation under subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the ‘Act’) and asked whether there was any information to provide concerning why the eviction should be delayed or refused.
  The Tenants explained that they had hastily accepted an unmanageable payment plan in the original agreement only to save their tenancy.  They explained that their circumstances have changed now that the Tenant KT is working and they would be able to respect a more reasonable plan to repay the arrears by April 2011 instead of February 2011 as in the original agreement.  They have three children with a fourth child on the way and would find it very difficult on the family to have to find a new home.
  The Landlord was sceptical of the Tenants’ ability to respect a new payment plan.
  Determinations:
  1.        The mediated settlement provided that the Landlord could apply to the Board under section 78 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act') without notice to the Tenants to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenants if they did not meet certain condition(s) specified in the settlement.
2.        I find that the Tenants have not met the following conditions specified in the settlement: The Tenants were to pay $4,500.00 towards the arrears on or before January 6, 2011 but only paid $1,500.00.
3.        The previous application included a request for an order for the payment of arrears of rent. The resulting mediated settlement required the Tenants to pay rent or some or all of the arrears of rent. Accordingly, in addition to eviction, the Landlord is entitled to request an order for the payment of arrears of rent and compensation.
4.        The application under section 78 of the Act would normally have resulted in an ex parte order.
5.        The application under section 78 of the Act went to a hearing due to confusing amounts listed in the application.
6.        Any matter brought before the Board that involves eviction of the Tenants obliges the Board Member to consider relief from eviction under section 83 of the Act.
7.        I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would not be unfair to grant relief from eviction subject to the condition(s) set out in this order pursuant to subsection 83(1)(a) and 204(1) of the Act.
8.        In order to provide relief from eviction I find it reasonable to replace the mediated agreement with a new Order.

  1.        The settlement mediated by the Board on October 28, 2010 with respect to application EAL10801 is cancelled and replaced by this Order.

Order under Subsection 21.2 of the

and the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
  File Number: EAL-11865-10-RV
     
Review Order
  FT (the 'Landlord') applied for an order requiring RR (the 'Tenant') to pay the rent that he owes.
  This application was resolved by order EAL-11865-10 issued on December 21, 2010.
  On January 20, 2011, the Tenant requested a review of the order.
  The request was heard in Ottawa on February 10, 2011.  The Landlord’s representative, KB, and the Tenant, attended the hearing.
  Determinations:
  1.        Order EAL-11865-10 issued on December 21, 2010, contains a serious error in law in the determination made by the Member.  The Landlord did not impose an air conditioning charge on the Tenant.  The Tenant signed the lease and initialled each page on October 10, 2006.  Paragraph 58 strictly prohibits the installation of an air conditioner when the Landlord provides the electricity unless permission is grant in writing.
  2.        Starting in June 2008 the Landlord began posting written notices informing tenants that there would be an additional charge if they chose to install an air-conditioner for the summer months.  The tenants were informed that the seasonal charge would be $50.00.  This charge is allowed in the Residential Tenancies Act in section 123 of the Act and section 16 of the Regulation 516/06.
  3.        I find there was a written agreement from the Landlord to allow tenants to install air-conditioners provided the tenants pay the reasonable cost of electricity.  By installing an air-conditioner a tenant is agreeing to pay the fee.
  4.        The Tenant argues that he had installed an air-conditioner from the beginning of his tenancy and because he was not required to pay for the electricity prior to 2008 it was implied that this service was a part of the tenancy agreement.  Where a tenancy agreement strictly prohibits an activity or service and the agreement is signed by a tenant, a tenant cannot unilaterally breach that agreement and claim that the tenancy agreement has been amended because of those actions.  As an example, if a tenant has been hanging laundry on a balcony and that is prohibited, it does become an implied right to hang the laundry on the balcony.
  5.        The Tenant was in possession of the rental unit on the date the application was filed.
  6.        The Tenant did not pay the total rent he was required to pay for the period from June 1, 2008 to August 31, 2010.
  It is ordered that:
  1.        Order EAL-11865-10 issued on December 21, 2010 is cancelled and replaced by the following:
2.        The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $350.00, which represents the amount of rent owing up to August 31, 2008.

ID and PW (the 'Landlords') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict LT the 'Tenant') because the Tenant did not pay the rent that the Tenant owes (L-1 application).
  And
  The Landlords applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenant because the Tenant gave a notice to terminate the tenancy (L-3 application).  The matter was resolved by Order EAL-12316-10 issued on December 15, 2010.
The Tenant filed a motion to set aside order EAL-12316-10.
  And
  The Tenant applied for an order determining that the Landlords or the Landlord's superintendent or the Landlord's agent entered the rental unit illegally, substantially interfered with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit or residential complex by the Tenant or by a member of her household and withheld or deliberately interfered with the reasonable supply of a vital service, care service, or food that the Landlord is obligated to supply under the tenancy agreement (T-2 application).
  These applications and this motion were heard together in Brockville on January 31, 2011.  The Landlords and the Tenant attended the hearing.  The Tenant was represented by JK.   KG testified on behalf of the Tenant.
  I notified the parties of my obligation under subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the ‘Act’) and asked whether there was any information to provide concerning why the eviction should be delayed or refused. The Landlords did not provide any such information.
  The Tenant argued that eviction should be refused as she did not agree to terminate the tenancy and that she is not in arrears of rent as the Landlords owe her money.
  Issues raised by the Tenant at the hearing:
  The Tenant decided to withdraw the portion of the application referring to illegal entry into the unit.
  The Tenant alleged the following: that the Landlords reduced the floor space of her unit without providing her with the agreed upon compensation, that the Tenant was exposed to the dust and debris of the renovations in the unit above hers (shared ventilation) as well as the renovations related to the sectioning of her rental unit to reduce the floor space, that the exposure to the dust and debris made her sick with asthma, that the Landlords failed to provide heat from the primary source of heating (the furnace) to her unit in October 2010, that the Landlords failed to provide hot water during a four day period in August 2010, and that all of these issues contributed to substantially interference with her reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit.
  The Tenant requested compensation in the form of a rent rebate and also asked for compensation related to the Landlords making her sick with asthma.
  Determinations:
                      L-1 application
1.        The Tenant has not paid the total rent she was required to pay for the period from November 1, 2010 to February 28, 2011.  Because of the arrears, the Landlords served a Notice of Termination effective November 25, 2010.
2.        Prior to any rent rebate, the Tenant owes $2,016.00 (this amount represents arrears and costs owed up to February 28, 2011).
3.        The Tenant is entitled to a rebate of rent of $3,200.00 in compensation for the issues in the Tenant’s application (see below).
4.        The Landlords owe the Tenant $1,184.00 (rebate minus rent owed).
                    L-3 application
5.        I find that there was no meeting of the minds to terminate the tenancy.
                    T-2 application
6.        I find that the Tenant was paying $650.00 in monthly rent for the unit when the tenancy started in September of 2007.
7.        I find that the ex-husband of the Landlord (PW) lent the Landlords the money to purchase the residential complex and was very influential in how the Landlords managed the residential complex and dealt with the Tenant.
8.        I find that the Landlords reduced the Tenant’s floor space by approximately 40% at least one year prior (December 2009) to the date the Tenant filed her application (December 3, 2010).
9.        I find that the parties had initially agreed to reduce the rent by $200.00 per month with respect to the reduced floor space.
10.   I find that the Landlords continued to charge the Tenant $650.00 in monthly rent after reducing the Tenant’s floor space by approximately 40%.
11.   I find that the Landlords were aware of the Tenant’s issues with mental health (depression and suicide attempts).
12.   I find that the Landlords played on the good will of the Tenant to delay compensating her (with reduced rent) for the reduced floor space and to eventually offer her insufficient alternate compensation.
13.   I find that the Landlords and (PW)’s ex-husband (Landlords’ agent) only provided the Tenant with part of the full cable services she was promised (television, high speed internet, and internet phone service) as alternate compensation for the reduced floor space.
14.   I find that the unreliable phone service (internet phone service shared with (PW)’s ex-husband) supplied by the Landlords forced the Tenant to have to use pay phones at crucial times and substantially interfered with the Tenant’s reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit.
15.   I find that the Landlords have substantially interfered with the Tenant’s reasonable enjoyment of her unit by reducing her floor space without providing proper compensation.
16.   I find that it would be reasonable to provide the Tenant with a rent rebate of $3,000.00 ($200.00 per month from December 2009 to February 2011) with respect to the reduction of the Tenant’s floor space.
17.   I find it reasonable that a $200.00 monthly rebate should continue to be provided to the Tenant as long as the Tenant’s floor space is reduced from the space that was allotted at the beginning of the tenancy.
18.   I find that the Tenant was exposed to the dust and debris related to the renovation work that reduced the Tenant’s floor space. I find that the Landlords failed to clean up the dust and debris until the end of December 2009, and that this lack of action on the part of the Landlords substantially interfered with the Tenant’s reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit.
19.   I find it reasonable to compensate the Tenant with a rent rebate of $200.00 for the month of December 2009 when the Tenant was exposed to the dust and debris.
20.   The total rebate to the Tenant is $3,200.00.
21.   I find that the Landlords or the Landlord’s agent interfered with the reasonable supply of heat from the furnace to the Tenants’ unit during the month of October 2010, and the supply of hot water for a four day period in August 2010.
22.   I find that the Tenant did not substantiate the impact of the Landlords’ interference with the supply of these vital services and did not request compensation for this issue.
23.   I find that the Tenant failed to prove on the balance of probabilities that the Landlords’ actions were responsible for her illness.
    It is ordered that:
                      L-3 application
1.        Order EAL-12316-10 issued on December 15, 2010, is set aside and cannot be enforced.
                    L-1 and T-2 applications
2.        The Landlords shall pay to the Tenant $1,184.00 which is the difference between the rent rebate of $3,200.00 awarded to the Tenant and the amount of $2,016.00 owed by the Tenant for arrears of rent and costs.
3.        The Landlords shall pay the Tenant the full amount owing by February 27, 2011.
4.        If the Landlords do not pay the Tenant the full amount owing by February 27, 2011, they will owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from February 28, 2011 at 3.00% annually on the balance outstanding.
5.        If the Landlords do not pay the Tenant the full amount owing by February 27, 2011, the Tenant may recover this amount by deducting $450.00 from the rent each month staring March 1, 2011 until the full amount has been recovered.
6.        Starting March 1, 2011, the Landlords shall provide the Tenant with an ongoing monthly rent rebate of $200.00 for as long as the Tenant’s floor space is reduced from the space that was allotted at the beginning of the tenancy.
7.        The Tenant has the right, at any time, to collect the full amount owing or any balance outstanding under this order.

  REASONS
     
In the matter of:
BASEMENT, 854 KINGSMERE AVENUE

        Between:

  Landlords
        and
          Joseph Petit 
Teresita Camoro
  Tenants
          Reasons to Order EAL-18297-11 issued on November 1, 2011 by Wayne MacKinnon.
  The Landlords applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenants for the Landlord’s own use.
  This application was heard in Ottawa on October 6, 2011. The Landlords and the Tenants, and their respective Counsels, attended the hearing.
    The Landlords failed to demonstrate that they met the requirements of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the’Act’) pursuant to section 48.  The Landlords also failed to demonstrate that they were making this application ‘in good faith’ because the Landlords’ daughter wanted to use this rental unit only occasionally. The daughter lives with her husband and another child (a son) in the family home within this city. It is most unlikely that the Landlord’s daughter would be intending to use this rental unit as her main residence, based on the evidence she provided with respect to not leaving her husband and son alone in the family home. In other words this arrangement would be use of the rental unit on an intermittent or casual basis. The daughter also gave evidence that she was returning to work after a maternity leave and she wanted or needed her parents to babysit the younger child. She also stated that she would be staying with her parents four or five days a week. This is not the intention of this section of the Act. No matter which way we look at this application, it always returns to the fact that his would not be the primary residence of the daughter and her newborn daughter, and also she would not be residing in the rental unit on a full-time basis.
  The Tenants were insistent on the fact that the Landlords were not acting in good faith, because this was a basement unit and the female Landlord (mother of the daughter who wants to move in) was not even able to climb the necessary stairs (due to a disability) to take care of the baby in the rental unit, during the time that the daughter was at work. 
The Landlords invoked, at one point in the hearing, the fact that this is a cultural trait. It was a cultural thing that people from the Phillipines tended to have their children looked after by other family Members when it is not possible to be present themselves. I find that that is a normal way of life for most other cultural minorities. The Landlords already occupy part of the residential complex, and have ample room/space to babysit their grandchild on a regular basis.
  A commentator on the Act sets out that “the test of good faith under section 48 is a genuine intention to occupy the premises (the rental unit), not the reasonableness of the Landlord’s proposal.” I find that, in this case, there is no genuine intention to occupy this rental unit on a full time basis. Consequently this application cannot succeed.

  The Tenants applied for an order determining that the Landlords gave a notice of termination in bad faith and for an order determining that the Landlords harassed, obstructed, coerced, threatened or interfered with them.
  These applications were heard in Ottawa on November 2, 2011.  The Landlords, represented by DL, and the Tenant SH, attended the hearing.  Witness for the Tenant TO, also attended and testified.
  At the hearing, the Tenant SH requested the consent of the Board to withdraw their applications.
  In accordance with subsection 200(4) of the Act, I consent to the withdrawal of the applications.
  The Issue:
  On July 20, 2011, the Landlords served an N12 notice for landlord’s own use on the Tenants terminating the tenancy on October 31, 2011.  The term of the lease signed between the Landlord JZ and the Tenants on September 14, 2008 ends on October 31, 2011.  The Tenant SH introduced into evidence a new lease he claims was signed on February 11, 2011 which commences on October 1, 2011 and continues for 54 months until March 31, 2016.  The Tenant therefore contends that the N122 is invalid because the termination on the notice must be the day a period ends, or where the tenancy is for a fixed term, the end of the term.  The Landlords claim they never entered into this new lease with the Tenants.
      Determinations:
  1.        The term of the lease between the Landlords and the Tenants ends on October 31, 2011.  The Landlords did not enter into a new tenancy agreement with the Tenants beyond October 31, 2011.
2.        The Landlords collected a rent deposit of $1,500.00 from the Tenants and this deposit is still being held by the Landlords.
3.        Interest on the rent deposit is owing to the Tenants for the period from September 14, I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would be unfair to grant relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act.
It is ordered that:
  1.        The tenancy between the Landlords and the Tenants is terminated.  The Tenants must move out of the rental unit on or before November 18, 2011.
2.        As of the date of this order, the amount the Landlords is holding for the rent deposit and the interest owing on the deposit exceeds the amount the Tenants owe for compensation by $1,373.12.
3.        The Landlords is authorized to offset from the amount the Landlords owe the Tenants the following amounts: $49.32 per day for compensation for the use of the unit from November 8, 2011  to the date the Tenants  move out of the unit; and $170.00 for the cost of filing the application.
4.        The Landlords or the Tenants may collect from the other any money that becomes owing as a result of this order.
5.        If the unit is not vacated on or before November 18, 2011, then starting November 19, 2011, the Landlords may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.

EAT-18777-11
  REASONS
         
Reasons to Order EAL-18631-11 issued on November 4, 2011 by Greg Joy.
  GZ and JZ (the 'Landlords') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict SH and EC (the 'Tenants') because the Landlords require the rental unit for personal use.  The Landlords also claimed compensation for each day the Tenants remained in the unit after the termination date.
  The Tenants applied for an order determining that the Landlords gave a notice of termination in bad faith and for an order determining that the Landlords harassed, obstructed, coerced, threatened or interfered with them.
  These applications were heard in Ottawa on November 2, 2011.  The Landlords, represented by DL, and the Tenant SH, attended the hearing.  Witness for the Tenant TO, also attended and testified.
  Findings of Fact:
  The Tenant’s witness to the signature of the Landlord GZ did not see her sign the document and did not see her at the rental unit at the time the Tenant claims the parties agreed to the new lease.
  The signatures on the new lease are dated February 11, 2011, more than 8 ½ months before the end of the existing lease.
  The existing lease was to expire on October 31, 2011 and the new lease was to commence October 1, 2011, one month before the existing lease would end.
  The new lease includes a last month rent deposit which had previously been collected.
  The new lease has type written initials for the Landlord GZ and the Tenant SH while the other two leases the Landlord introduced as evidence, one between the Landlords and the Tenants and another from separate unit, have personal initials.
  The existing lease named the Landlord JZ while the new lease names both JZ and GZ as landlords.
  The signature on the new does not appear to match the signature of GZ on the sign in sheet for the hearing.
  The rent the Tenant claims the Landlord’s accepted for October 2011 rent was deposited at a branch the Landlords testified is not one of the two branches they do business.
  Analysis and Conclusion:
  The Tenant claims that the Landlord GZ approached him in early February 2011 asking him to renew the existing lease which was to end on October 31, 2011, nearly 9 months later, for a 54 month term.  GZ denies that she ever spoke to the Tenant about a new lease and testified that she does not deal with this aspect of the business and has never met the Tenant.  GZ testified that her husband deals with tenants and signs the leases and that she deals with the finances of the business.  The Landlords introduced the lease they have with another tenant and testified that they no longer use the type of lease that the Tenant claims they both signed in February 2011.  The lease introduced as evidence is totally different from the lease in question.  The new lease is the same design as the Ontario Real Estate Association ‘Form 400’ used for the original lease signed between the parties.
  GZ testified that she has never met the Tenant SH.  SH claims that she met him once during the three year tenancy when there was a flood in the unit and that she must know who he is because he cuts the grass and she can see him from their business.  Testimony shows that the Landlord JZ and their son attended to the flood and that their son was at the rental unit several times during that period of time to repair the problems from the flood.  The Landlords and their son deny that GZ was at the rental unit at the time of the flood.  I find it peculiar that SH would claim that GZ approached him about a new long term lease when there was at most one interaction between them during the tenancy and that was when the Landlord JZ and their son were at the unit to investigate a flood.  It was JZ who signed the original lease and dealt with problems such as the flood.  Even if I accepted the testimony from SH that GZ came to the unit after the flood, to accept that GZ approached SH to extend the lease for 54 months more than 8 ½ months before the end of the lease is inconsistent with the landlord/ tenant relationship established between the parties.
  I also find the inconsistencies in the new lease to be suspect.  The Landlord’s have several rental properties, both residential and commercial, and have been in the business for several years.   When questioned about the length of the new lease, there was no testimony or evidence presented that would lead me to believe there was an understanding between the parties that the lease would be extended for 4 ½ years.  I also find it peculiar that the Landlords would present a lease that would begin a full month before the old lease ends, be signed by only one of the Landlords when both are named on the front page, that the initials on the pages are type written when the other leases introduced as evidence are initialled by the parties to the leases, that the last month rent deposit would be required on the new lease when the Landlords are holding a last month rent deposit, and the signature of GZ does not appear to match her signature on the sign-in sheet for the hearing.
  I find it unusual that the Tenant’s witness, an OPP officer, would sign the lease as witness to the Landlord (GZ) and the Tenant SH signing the lease, when in fact he didn’t get up from the couch to see the document being signed by GZ and didn’t see her at the rental unit on February 11, 2011.  Considering the fact that GZ denies signing the lease and the witness did not actually witnesses GZ sign the document, I cannot conclude that GZ signed the lease.
  Although the Landlords did not bring evidence to support their testimony that they do not do business at the Westgate Shopping Centre Royal Bank of Canada, where the rent cheque fro October 2011 was deposited to their account, but instead do business at two other branches, this testimony was not challenged by SH at the hearing.  It seems peculiar that the October 2011 rent would be deposited at a branch were the Landlords do not do business and that they would deposit a rent cheque for a period covered by the last month rent deposit due to the October 31, 2011 termination date on the N12 notice they served on the Tenants.
  Considering all of the inconsistencies and highly unusual circumstances surrounding the signing of the lease, the term of the new lease, and the unusual length of time before the end of the existing lease, I conclude that the Landlords did not enter into a new tenancy agreement with the Tenants and that the end of the term on the lease between the parties was October 31, 2011.

File Number: EAL-18768-11
  REASONS
         
Reasons to Order EAL-18768-11 issued on November 24, 2011 by Gerald Naud.
  The Landlord applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenant because she or another occupant of the rental unit has committed an illegal act or has carried out, or permitted someone to carry out an illegal trade, business or occupation in the rental unit or the residential complex. The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenant remained in the unit after the termination date.
  This application was heard in Ottawa on November 15, 2011.
  The Landlord’s representative, LC, the Tenant and the Tenant’s representative, RM attended the hearing.
  The Tenant and the Community Worker testified on behalf of the Tenant.  The Landlord had four witnesses testify on their behalf.
  The Tenant provided the Board with a Board Decision TSL-12789-11 issued on February 16, 2011 and an excerpt Toronto community Housing Corp. V. Clarke (2006), 2006 Carswell Ont 2139, [2006] O.J. No. 2711.
  The Landlord provided the Board with an Ontario Superior Court of Justice, Divisional Court decision Robert Connelly v. Mary Lambert Swale Non-Profit Homes.(2006) Court file no: 7/06; British Columbia Provincial Court , Criminal Division, R. v. Felix [1994] B.C.J. No.1580; Supreme Court of Canada; R. v. Clemente [1994] 2.S.C.R. 758, File No: 23931.
  The incidents of September 27, 2011 to October 3, 2011.
  The Landlord’s property manager and a maintenance staff were having a meeting when the Tenant walked by and started to yell at them and then proceeded to follow the Landlord’s property manager and impeded on her personal space while using profanities at this time. When the Tenant was politely asked to step away, the Tenant again walked into the Tenant’s face.  The Tenant had difficulty hearing the content of the Tenant’s threats because she was so frighten by the Tenant’s physical imposition.
  A few minutes after the first incident, the Tenant called the Landlord’s call center.  The call was recorded and presented at the hearing. The Tenant admits that she threaten to kill the property manager. 
  Sometime after the incident, the Tenant had a meeting with the Tenant Community Worker and told him that she could have the property manager kidnapped and raped.
  The first incident occurred on a Tuesday, the property manager opted to take the rest of the week off and returned to work on Monday October 3, 2011.  Upon her return to work she discover in her mail box five separate voice messages from the Tenant that were recorded and presented at the hearing.  The first message says “ How would you like to be raped?”.  The second message says “Pay back is a bitch”. The Third message says “Fucking cunt”. The fourth message is unclear and the fifth message is an apology.
  Did the Tenant commit an illegal Act?
  According to the Supreme Court Decision R. v. Clemente provided by the Landlord states
  “ The intent required under s. 264.1(1)(a), which is aimed at preventing “threats, can be framed in either of the two ways put forward.  Firstly, a serious threat to kill or cause serious bodily harm must have been uttered with the intent to intimidate or instill fear.  Conversely, such a threat uttered with intent to intimidate or cause fear must have been uttered with the intent that it be taken seriously.”
  The Tenant does not dispute that she uttered the words.  The words spoken by the Tenant and the description of the incident on September 27, 2011 and the continuation of the threat to kill or cause bodily harm to the property manager in other voice messages, clearly disturbed and intimidated the property manager.  There is no doubt that the Tenant spoke the words threatening the property manager of death and bodily harm.  This is the act of the offence. The Tenant’s delivery of the threats such as impeding in the property manager’s space, the intensity, the repeated phone calls are all facts clearly indicating that the Tenant formulating the seriousness of intention to intimidate or instill fear in the property manager and the other people who heard the Tenants words.
  The Tenant’s representatives submits that since the Tenant does not have the capacity to execute these threats ” words are merely words”. In the case TSL-12789-11, the Tenant has been living for 9 years in a supportive housing for persons with mental health issues.  The Tenant made a threat to another tenant.  The other tenant was not present at the hearing and the Landlord only had a letter from the other tenant while the Tenant denied ever saying these words.  Therefore, the Board member states “ I was not satisfied that the Tenant’s behaviour seriously impaired or has seriously impaired the safety as required by Act.”
  In our case, the evidence demonstrates that the Tenant acted with intention and therefore committed an illegal contrary to section 264.1(1)a of the Code.  Whether the Tenant has the capacity to carry out the threat is irrelevant to the determination that the Tenant committed an illegal act. However, I will explore this argument in my reasons on whether I should grant the Tenant relief from eviction.
  The Tenant is not disputing that she uttered these threats. 
  The Tenant is seeking relief from eviction.
  Based on Letter dated October 18, 2011, the doctor LM, states that “our office highly suspects that she suffers form Post Traumatic Stress Disorder as well as chronic addictions.” Therefore, I am of the opinion that the Tenant is disabled within the meaning of section 17(2) of the Human Rights Code ( the ’Code’) which states:
  “No Tribunal or court shall find a person incapable unless it is satisfied that the needs of the person cannot be accommodated without undue hardship on the person responsible for accommodating those needs, considering, the cost, outside sources of funding, if any, and health and safety requirements, if any.”
  At the hearing, the Tenant was unable to propose an accommodation plan that the Landlord could implement to prevent a reoccurrence of this type of incident.
  Was the incident between September 27, 2011 and October 3, 2011 an isolated incident?
What are the chances of a reoccurrence?
  At the hearing another tenant testified that on or about October 15, 2011, while she was gardening outside, the Tenant came over and threaten to “beat me in the face”.
  According to a written report from the Landlord, On October 30, 2011 at 02:07 AM, another tenant is reporting that he is having difficulties with the Tenant “ she is coming to his door and threatening him to have him beat up, etc.).
  I have no reason not to believe that these two other incidences occurred.  The September 27, 2011 to October 3, 2011 incident is not an isolated incident.
  The Tenant’s representative submits that the Tenant does not have the capacity to execute the threats. I have no evidence to determine whether she will carry out or have someone carry out the threat. This application is concerning the Tenant committing an illegal act. If she carries out the threats it becomes another illegal act.
  The fact that the Tenant has a disability does not mean that we need to relax the standards of conduct for that individual.  For example, someone who is physically disabled and is confined to a wheel chair and while waiving a large knife utters that he will kill the next person that passes in the hallway.  Because of his physical disability do we automatically conclude that he cannot execute the threats and that we should relax the standard of behaviour for an illegal act.
  In this case, I do not have sufficient evidence that the Tenant’s TPDS and additions are the cause to her committing illegal acts.  I do not have sufficient evidence that the Tenant cannot carry out the threats.  I have insufficient legal reference that the standard of behaviour for an illegal act should be relaxed in similar situation.
  For all these reasons and circumstances, I find that the tenant should not be given relief from the eviction with the exception of granting her approximately fifteen days to find a new place to live.

  REASONS
             
Reasons to Order EAL-18484-11-SA issued on December 1, 2011 by Régent Gagnon.
  DR (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict SS (the 'Tenant') and for an order to have the Tenant pay the rent and compensation she owes because she failed to meet a condition specified in order EAL-10855-11 issued on November 26, 2010.
  The Landlord's application was resolved by order EAL-18484-11, issued on September 23, 2011, amended on October 25, 2011 and further amended on November 7, 2011. On November 15, 2011, the Tenant filed a motion to set aside order EAL-18484-11.
  This motion was heard in Ottawa on November 30, 2011.
  The Landlord’s legal representative, EMG and the Tenant attended the hearing. Duty Counsel assisted the Tenant.
    Reasons for amendments
  The Landlord’s initial request to amend order EAL-18484-11, issued on September 23, 2011 was because the order contained a termination date that was 17 days before the date of the Landlord’s application. This was a Board mistake that the Member failed to notice before signing the order. The Member issued an amended order on October 25, 2011.
  On November 4, 2011, the Landlord filed a second request to amend the order. This time, it was because the Landlord specified an incorrect address for the Tenant in his application. The Member made a further amendment to his amended order, but did not change the amended date. Board records show that this second amended order was mailed to the parties on November 7, 2011.
    Consequences of the Landlord’s failure to provide the Board with the Tenant’s correct address
  The Tenant did not receive any of the Board’s orders. She became aware of the proceedings only after receiving an eviction notice from the Sheriff. On November 10, 2011, the Landlord went to the Sheriff’s office to enforce the order issued on November 7, 2011, which had the correct address for the rental unit.
  The Landlord’s error prevented the Tenant from exercising her rights to file a motion to set aside order EAL-18484-11, issued on September 23, 2011, as well as the amended order issued on October 25, 2011. She exercised her rights as soon as she was aware of the existence of an ex-parte eviction order.
  The Landlord is requesting that the Tenant compensate it for the non-refundable fee paid to enforce the eviction order. I find on the balance of probabilities that had the Landlord used the correct address on the application for termination of the tenancy, the Tenant would have filed a motion to set aside the order upon receiving it. Therefore, the Tenant should not be liable for the errors of the Landlord.
    The Tenant’s breaches
  The Tenant paid the rent on time from December 1, 2010 to August 1, 2011. In September 2011, the Tenant was late by 7 days and did not try to hide this. She had been incapacitated by an illness and gave a cheque to the Landlord on September 7, 2011, two weeks before the Landlord filed the application.
  The Tenant gave to the Landlord a cheque dated October 2, 2011. Although this is a breach, this is an inconsequential one. October 1st was on a Saturday and the next business day was October 3rd.
  The Tenant paid the November rent on time. November 2011 was the final month in order EAL-10855-11 issued on November 26, 2010.
  I will order the Tenant to pay the rent on time for a six-month period to reinforce the responsibility of the Tenant to ensure the Landlord receive rent payments when due.

OCHC (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict CB (the 'Tenant') because she failed to meet a condition specified in the settlement mediated by the Board on June 29, 2011 with respect to application EAL-15572-11.
  The Landlord's application was resolved by order EAL-19651-11, issued on November 9, 2011. The Tenant filed a motion to set aside order EAL-19651-11.
  This motion was heard in Ottawa on December 6, 2011.
  The Landlord’s Legal Representative, GC and the Tenant attended the hearing.
  Determinations:
  1.        The mediated settlement provided that the Landlord could apply to the Board under section 78 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act') without notice to the Tenant to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenant if she did not meet certain condition(s) specified in the settlement.
2.        I find that the Tenant has not met the following condition specified in the settlement: The Tenant held a garage sale in the common area of the residential complex on November 1 and November 2, 2011 contrary to what she had agreed to in the settlement mediated by the Board.
3.        The Tenant pled guilty and was given a $140.00 fine for contravening Zoning-By-Law NO.2002-189 which prohibits individuals from having engaged in the sale of second hand goods more than two times in the same calendar year.
4.        I therefore find that the Tenant committed an illegal act.
5.        The Tenant had previously filed an application against the Landlord complaining of pests (bedbugs) in her unit.
6.        The Tenant is now aware that the Landlord has a policy prohibiting tenants from engaging in the sale of second hand goods on the premises of the residential complex as part of the Landlord’s strategy to combat the problem of pest infestation in the residential complex.
7.        The Tenant is now aware that the Landlord has been warned by the Municipality that the Landlord may be charged and fined if it permits tenants to engage in the sale of second hand goods on the premises of the residential complex.  Such activity by any tenant in the future would then interfere with the Landlord’s rights, privileges and interests.
8.        By engaging in the sale of second hand goods, The Tenant has substantially interfered with the Landlord’s rights, privileges and interests.
9.        The Tenant has agreed not to engage in the sale of any second hand goods on the premises of the residential complex for the duration of the tenancy.
10.   The Tenant has agreed to refrain from making discriminatory or derogatory comments to the Landlord, his employees or agents.
11.   I find it reasonable to give the Tenant a last chance to change her behaviour and preserve her tenancy.
12.   Pursuant to sub-section 78(12) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006, I find it appropriate to replace the settlement mediated by the Board on June 29, 2011 with this Order.
It is ordered that:
  1.        Order EAL-19651-11, issued on November 9, 2011 is set aside and cannot be enforced.
2.        The settlement mediated by the Board on June 29, 2011 is amended to replace its terms and conditions by the following:
3.        The Tenant shall not commit an illegal act in the residential complex for the next twelve months from December 19, 2011 through to and including December 18, 2012.
4. RCHC (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict DZ (the 'Tenant') because the Tenant did not pay the rent that the Tenant owes.
  This application was heard in Pembroke on December 16, 2011.  The Landlord’s representative, LZ, and the Tenant, assisted by Duty Counsel, attended the hearing.  Also in attendance was DG, witness for the Landlord.
  Preliminary Matters:
  The Tenant requested an adjournment at the beginning of the hearing.  Considering the fact that this application was adjourned on four previous occasions; that the most recent adjournment was at the Tenant’s request to provide her time to file an application with the Board; that the interim order shows that the Tenant must file the application on or before November 28, 2011 and the application was not filed; that it was peremptory on the Tenant to be present and read to proceed; that the Tenant was to disclose all documents, photos and any other evidence she intended to rely on five days before the hearing to the Board and the Landlord and nothing had been disclosed; that the Landlord was not in agreement with the Tenant’s request to adjourn at the last hearing; and the fact the Tenant fired her legal aid lawyer just prior to the hearing; the request to adjourn was denied as I find this to be an abuse of process.
  The Tenant began her submissions wanting to raise issues under section 82 of the Residential Tenancies Act.  Duty Counsel was asked to meet with the Tenant while the matter was stood down so that the Tenant was aware of the problems with proceeding without sufficient evidence and the principle of res judicata.  After Duty Counsel met with the Tenant for approximately 30 minutes I was informed the Tenant wanted to address her issues and Duty Counsel assisted.
        Issues Raised Under Section 82:
  Water infiltration (flood) in late 2010; deteriorated drywall in the unit due to moisture; electrical safety; water dripping from light fixtures and light fixtures not functioning; a broken heater; disposal of a mattress and couch.
  Determinations:
  1.        Based on the fact the only evidence the Tenant had was a report about water infiltration in March 2009 and the Landlord denies there have been any water infiltration problems since that time, I find the Tenant has not supported her allegation of a flood in late 2010.
2.        The Tenant testified the drywall in the rental unit is severely damaged due to the flood.  The Landlord’s witness (DG), who has 40 years experience in fire and flood inspections and has recently inspected the Tenant’s rental unit, testified that he could find no evidence of water damage in the drywall anywhere in the unit.  This inspection took place after the Tenant had initially refused entry to the Landlord and the witness.  (DG) testified there is a missing soap dish in the bathroom but that the Tenant has refused entry to allow it to be replaced.  (DG) also testified that the reason the light fixture was not working is because the light bulb was burned out.  Despite the fact the Tenant is responsible to replace light bulbs, the Landlord provided the replacement bulb and the problem was remedied.  I find the Tenant has not support her allegation the drywall is in poor condition due to a flood and that there is a problem with the light fixture.
3.        The Tenant claims there is a problem with the electrical system in the rental unit.  The Landlord introduced a report from the Electrical Safety Authority date December 12, 2011 indicating that no defects were identified.  I find the Tenant has not supported her allegation there is a problem with the electrical system in the rental unit.
4.        The Tenant testified that the flood in late 2010 caused her mattress and couch to become so wet she had to place them outside.  The Tenant testified she moved the items outside in May 2011.  On August 26, 2011 after the items had remained behind the garbage containers for more than 3 months, the Landlord had them removed.  I do not accept the Tenant’s testimony that the Landlord is responsible for throwing away these items.  The Tenant placed them outside approximately 6 months after she claims there was a flood and left them there for another 3 months.  I find the Tenant abandoned this property and the Landlord rightfully disposed of them.
5.        The Tenant also claims the Landlord did not respond to a problem with a heater.  The heater was replaced and the Tenant did not prove the Landlord did not respond in a timely manner.
6.        The Tenant has not paid the total rent she was required to pay for the period from April 1, 2011 to December 31, 2011.  Because of the arrears, the Landlord served a Notice of Termination effective July 27, 2011.
7.        The Tenant paid $903.00 after the application was filed.
8.        Duty Counsel requested relief from termination of the tenancy by allowing the Tenant to pay an extra $100.00 per month to pay off the balance owing to the Landlord.  I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would not be unfair to postpone the eviction until January 31, 2012 pursuant to subsection 83(1)(b) of the Act.  This postponement is to allow the Tenant sufficient time to seek assistance to void this order.
    It is ordered that:
  1.        Unless the Tenant voids the order as set out below, the tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenant is terminated.  The Tenant must move out of the rental unit on or before January 31, 2012.
2.        The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $1,100.69*, which represents the amount of rent owing and compensation up to December 19, 2011.
3.        The Tenant shall also pay to the Landlord $9.90 per day for compensation for the use of the unit starting December 20, 2011 to the date she moves out of the unit.
4.        The Tenant shall also pay to the Landlord $170.00 for the cost of filing the application.
5.        If the Tenant does not pay the Landlord the full amount owing* on or before December 30, 2011, the Tenant will start to owe interest.  This will be simple interest calculated from December 31, 2011 at 3.00% annually on the balance outstanding.
6.        If the unit is not vacated on or before January 31, 2012, then starting February 1, 2012, the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
7.        Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlord, on or after February 1, 2012.
8.        If the Tenant wishes to void this order and continue the tenancy, she must pay to the Landlord or to the Board in trust:
i)        $1,374.00 if the payment is made on or before December 31, 2011, or
ii)      $1,675.00 if the payment is made on or before January 31, 2012**.
If the Tenant does not make full payment in accordance with this paragraph and by the appropriate deadline, then the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
9.        The Tenant may make a motion to the Board under subsection 74(11) of the Act to set aside this order if they pay the amount required under that subsection on or after February 1, 2012 but before the Sheriff gives vacant possession to the Landlord. The Tenant is only entitled to make this motion once during the period of the tenancy agreement with the Landlord.

  REASONS
     
In the matter of:
13, 250 MCKENZIE STREET

        Between:

  Landlord

          Michael Gutoskie
  Tenant
          Reasons to Order EAL-19611-11 issued on January 13, 2012 by Greg Joy.
  Aurel Boucher (AB) (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict Michael Gutoskie (MG) (the 'Tenant') because the Landlord requires possession of the rental unit for the purpose of residential occupation.
  This application was heard in Pembroke on January 6, 2012.
  The Landlord, his legal representative, Timothy Girard (TG), the Tenant and his legal representative, Amy Scholten (AS), attended the hearing. Loretta Moreau (W1) and Linda Boucher (W2) testified for the Landlord.
  Witnesses were excluded at the start of the hearing.
    Good faith
  Does the Landlord require possession of the rental unit for the purpose of residential occupation in good faith?
  W1 is the person who wants to move into the rental unit. She is the Landlord’s mother-in-law. She is 80 years old, has difficulty with stairs, and has heart and circulatory diseases and other medical conditions associated with her age.
  W1 currently lives in a somewhat winterized cottage in need of major work. Although not distant from the rental unit, it is somewhat isolated in the winter due to the layout of the roads and their condition that sometimes renders the cottage inaccessible by car or truck.
  W1 wants a rental unit that has no stairs, is close to the hospital and her physicians’ office and where she can get help readily from family members or friends.
The Tenant’s representative submitted that W1 could move to another rental unit owned by members of her family and that she has no intention of selling the cottage, where she would likely return in the summer. Therefore, she only wants to move in temporarily to accommodate the Landlord who wants to evict the Tenant on any ground that he can find.
  I find that whether or not W1 wants to keep the cottage is not an indication that she does not want to move into the rental unit. A person can have a residence and own a cottage for seasonal or intermittent use.
  I find that W1 has a genuine intent to move into the rental unit and that the Landlord made this application in good faith.
    Relations between the parties
  The Landlord tried to evict the Tenant at a hearing held on April 15, 2011 at which the Tenant’s application about maintenance was heard. The Landlord alleged that the Tenant wilfully or negligently caused a pipe in the heating system to freeze and break, causing damage to the rental unit of about $20,000.00. The Landlord’s application was dismissed.
  At that hearing, the Landlord said he needed to have the Tenant complete some documents for the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC) to determine if he is eligible to rent a unit in the residential complex where the rent is subsidized. The Landlord was under the impression that he could evict the Tenant if the Tenant did not comply. On January 6, 2012, the Landlord said that CMHC had accepted the Landlord’s mistake not to have the documents completed before the Tenant moving in and eviction on those grounds is no longer an issue.
  The Landlord appears to be still convinced that the flood that occurred in the rental unit was caused by the Tenant although he did not challenge the Board decision issued on May 13, 2011. He may want the Tenant to be evicted, but he must prove, on the balance of probabilities, that the application has merits sufficient to evict the Tenant.
    Relief from eviction
  The Tenant’s representative submitted that eviction should be denied under subsection 83(3) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (Act) because the Landlord’s application is retaliatory and the Landlord is in breach of maintenance obligations. A decision from the Divisional Court, about which the Court of Appeal refused to grant leave, is useful in this situation. In MacNeil v. 976445 Ontario Ltd, Divisional Court held that when a maintenance issue has been resolved and is no longer an issue at the hearing, clause 83(3)(a) of the Act does not apply. Similarly, Divisional Court held that the sole or primary reason for eviction must be retaliatory for subsection 83(3) to apply.
  The Tenant’s representative submitted into evidence photographs that show that repairs to walls were not completed after repairs to the damaged heating system. While necessary, these do not represent a serious breach of the Landlord’s maintenance obligations. Both parties said that the heating system was working properly at the time of the hearing. The Landlord may have been in a serious breach of his obligations when the heating system was allegedly not working, but there was no breach on January 6, 2012.
  I have to consider the impact of eviction on the Tenant and on the Landlord. While neither party is directly affected, the Tenant’s wife has restricted mobility and needs a rental unit that has doors sufficiently wide for a wheelchair. Much has been said about the low availability of such units in Pembroke and area.
The Landlord’s mother in law does not need a unit with doors wide enough for a wheelchair, but she cannot continue to live safely at the cottage. A unit in this residential complex would suit her medical needs.
  The Tenant’s wife will suffer some hardship if the Tenant cannot find a unit that meets her needs and the Landlord’s mother in law is currently suffering some hardship from living at the cottage. However, I will postpone the termination of the tenancy to February 29, 2012.

    REASONS
    Reasons to Orders EAL-21452-12 and EAT- 21719-12 issued on April 2, 2012 by John Nolan.
    (SDS) (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict (DJ and GK) (the 'Tenants') because the Tenants did not pay the rent that the Tenants owe.
And
  The Tenants applied for an order determining that the Landlord or the Landlord's superintendent or Landlord’s agent substantially interfered with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit or residential complex by the Tenants or by a member of their household.
  These applications were heard together in Ottawa on March 13, 2012.
  The Landlord, the Landlord’s Agent, (SS) and the Tenants attended the hearing.
    REASONS:
  The Landlord’s L-1 application for rent arrears:
  The Tenants did not contest the fact that they did not pay the rent that is claimed in the Landlord’s application.
  The Tenants’ T-2 application based on substantial interference with reasonable enjoyment:
  The Tenants’ position:
  The Tenants testified to the following:
  The Landlord gave the Tenants a two day notice around November 11, 2011, to tell them that a contractor would be working on the foundation and that the work would be finished in 10 days to 2 weeks.  The work went on for eleven weeks through Christmas and New Years and is still not finished.  The Tenant (DJ) is off during the winter because he works at a golf course and spends that time relaxing at home, and the Tenant (GK) is on ODSP and is at home as well. Both Tenants were disturbed by the constant banging to the point they could not hear the television.
  The contractor moved some of the belongings that they had stored under the carport into the back yard and did not cover them.  As a result their belongings were damaged by the snow.  The Landlord used their electricity and blew a breaker without telling them which resulted in the food in their freezer having been spoiled.  The contractor used their electricity throughout the whole period which resulted in a much higher electric bill.  Due to the work being done on the foundation, the Tenants were without a parking space for a period of 8 weeks and had to park on the street.  The Tenants were also without a second exit because the back door was blocked for 8 weeks.
  The Tenants were not claiming a rent abatement for November 2011 because they had already paid their rent and had only complained to the Landlord at the end of November 2011.  The Tenants paid their rent for February and March 2012 because the contractor had stopped working during that period.
  The Tenants requested compensation for the food that they lost in the amount of $150.00, compensation for the electricity used by the contractor in the amount of $260.00, and compensation for the belongings that were damaged from having been exposed to the weather in the amount of $200.00.  The Tenants also requested a 100% rent rebate for the months of December 2011 and January 2012, as well as an ongoing rebate of $100.00 until the work is completed.
  The Landlord’s position:
  The Landlord testimony showed the following:
  The Landlord bought the building in February 2011.  During the spring thaw, water leaked into the basement unit and damaged the walls.  When the walls were being repaired it was noticed that there was significant damage to the foundation that needed to be repaired.  The City issued an order on June 16, 2011 to remedy an unsafe building.  The order from the City was posted on the door of the building.  The Landlord had until the end of June to obtain an Engineer’s report and a building permit to repair the foundation. The Landlord discussed the issue with the Tenant (DJ) and they came to an understanding that the work would not be done in the summer so as not to interfere with the Tenants’ use of the yard during the summer.  The Tenant (DJ) called the Landlord at the end of October 2011 enquiring as to when the work would take place.  The Landlord told him that the work would start on November 8, 2011.  The Tenant asked for compensation related to the work done in November 2011 and the Landlord and the Tenants agreed on a 22% rent abatement for November, 2011. 
  While the contractors were working on the foundation, they discovered that the damage was more extensive than originally thought.  The work was terminated on December 22, 2011.
  The Landlord submitted a letter from the engineering firm dated February 23, 2012 showing that they found the repair and replacement of the damaged foundation wall to have been completed in general conformance with the approved construction drawings.
  The Landlord submitted 3 letters from the contractor who did the work.  The first letter showed that the work began from November 8, 2011 and was completed December 22, 2011 and that all work was done within the hours permitted by the City’s noise by-laws.  The contractor explains in the letter that the driveway was obstructed for a period of five weeks until December 9, 2011, but room was maintained for one vehicle at the end of the driveway.  The second letter showed that during the waterproofing process, the contractor required a power source to connect the heater.  The contractor used the closest outlet which overloaded the circuit and caused the breaker to trip. After having the breaker reset a few times the contractor gave up and drew power from inside the basement unit instead for the duration of the work.  When informed by the Tenants that the tripped breaker caused the meat in their freezer to spoil, the contractor had offered to submit a claim to his insurance company if the Tenants were to come forward with evidence to substantiate their loss so that he could provide the receipts to his insurance for reimbursement.  However the Tenants never followed up on his offer.  The third letter showed that all the tenants had been advised to clear the perimeter of the house of any items.  On the first day of work, the Tenant from the basement unit had already complied with the request.  The contractor stored the Tenants remaining items under a corrugated steel shelter opened on three ends because the Tenant (GK) who was at home at the time was unable to move the items himself.  At no point while the contractor was on sight did the Tenants express any concern for the items that were placed in the yard.
  The Landlord submitted a letter from the Tenant in the basement unit that shows that the contractors were on sight from November 8, 2011 to December 23, 2011.
  Analysis:
  Issue of credibility:
  I found the Landlord’s evidence and testimony to be consistent and credible and I preferred it to that of the Tenants which I found to be inconsistent on several levels.  One example of inconsistent testimony from the Tenants was their testimony about the duration of the interference with their reasonable enjoyment. 
  The Tenants testified that they did not claim a rent abatement for November 2011 because they had already paid the rent for that month.  The Landlord’s evidence was that he had provided the Tenants with a 22% rent abatement for November 2011 in relation to the work that was being done on the foundation.  In response to the Landlord’s evidence, the Tenants testified that they did receive a 22% rent abatement for November 2011 but that it had been given to them as compensation for mould issues and a door that stuck on a bump in the floor. If the Tenants’ complaint of interference with their reasonable enjoyment is related to the work on the foundation that started November 8, 2011 as well as the short notice they received about the work to be done, it does not make sense that they would not be claiming a rent rebate related to November 2011 when the work began.  The Tenants adduced no evidence to corroborate their story of a rent rebate and I find the Landlord’s version of the 22% rent rebate for November 2011 to be more plausible on the balance of probabilities.
  A second example of inconsistency in the Tenants’ testimony is their testimony regarding a lack of notice for the work to be done.  They testified that they had only been given a couple of days notice from the Landlord that work was to begin on the foundation in November 2011 and were not given the minimum sixty day notice required by the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006.  They admitted after the Landlord had provided his evidence that they were aware of the City’s order to remedy an unsafe building, a notice which was posted on the door of the building in June 2011.  I therefore find that the Tenants were aware of the imminent nature of the work to be done more than sixty days before it began in November 2011.  I believe on the balance of probabilities that the Landlord did have a discussion and agreement with the Tenant (DJ) to postpone the work so as not to interfere with the Tenants’ use of the yard during the summer. 
  Another example of inconsistent testimony was when the Tenants testified that the work lasted 11 weeks (which was more than the two weeks they were told it would last), that the work carried on through Christmas and New years and that it is still not complete.  As a consequence, the Tenants were requesting a 100% rent rebate for the Months of December 2011 and January 2012 as well as an ongoing monthly rebate of $100.00 until the work is terminated.  After the Landlord provided his evidence about the duration of the work, the Tenants were unable to substantiate that any work had been carried on after December 23, 2012.  I believe that the Tenants attempted to embellish their argument with reference to work being done over two important holidays when there was no evidence to corroborate that allegation.  I find that the Tenants have failed to convince me on the balance of probabilities that the work went beyond December 23, 2012.
  Issue of compensation for lost food:
  I believe on the balance of probabilities that the contractor offered to make a claim with his insurance company with respect to any frozen goods that may have been lost by the Tenants when the breaker was tripped by the contactor. The Tenants were never able to provide the contractor with any evidence of the alleged loss to show his insurer and the Tenants did not have any evidence to corroborate their allegation before the Board.  I therefore find that the Tenants have failed to convince me on the balance of probabilities that they sustained a loss due to the contractor having tripped a breaker related to the Tenants’ unit.
  Issue of compensation for electricity used by the contractor:
  The Tenants testified that the contractor has been using their electricity for the duration of the work that they alleged went on for 11 weeks and used the equivalent of $260.00 worth of electricity for which the Tenants had been billed.  In contrast, the letter from the contractor showed that the contractor had used the basement tenant’s electricity for the duration of the project after the breaker had to be reset in the Tenants’ unit. In examining the Ottawa Hydro bill submitted into evidence by the Tenants, I find that the bill shows a charge of $345.84 for the two month period ending December 15, 2011.  The charge for the following two month period ending February 16, 2012 is for $290.83. I believe on the weight of the evidence before me that the foundation work stopped on December 23, 2011 at the latest.  There is an approximate difference of $55.00 between the Hydro bill for the period when the work was going and the two month period there was no work.  The Tenants’ evidence does not substantiate that the contractor used $260.00 worth of electricity.  I am not convinced on the balance of probabilities that the contractor used a meaningful amount of the Tenants’ electricity, and it is impossible for me to determine how much of the $55.00 difference can be attributed to seasonal changes.  It would therefore not be appropriate to award the Tenants any compensation with respect to their electricity bill.
  Issue of compensation for items damaged by the contractor:
  The Tenants failed to convince me on the balance of probabilities that they did not know their possessions had been moved to an unprotected area of the yard.  The Tenants have a duty to minimize losses pursuant to section 16 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 and should have moved the very visible items to another location if they were worried about them being damaged by the elements, or at the very least asked the contractor to move them elsewhere.  The Tenants submitted no evidence to corroborate their allegation that items were damaged.  The Tenants submitted no evidence to support their claim of a loss of $200.00 related to the items in question.  It would therefore not be appropriate to award any compensation to the Tenants for the alleged damaged items.
  Issue of compensation for interference with reasonable enjoyment:
  Section 8 of the regulations O. Reg.516/06 provides for the conditions when a rent abatement is justified with respect to interference with reasonable enjoyment during repairs. 
  Since both tenants were at home during the repairs, the Tenants allege that the foundation work substantially interfered with the Tenants’ reasonable enjoyment of the unit due to the constant noise and vibration that prevented them from hearing their television set. 
  It is clear from the Work Order from the City that the foundation work done by the Landlord was necessary to protect or restore the physical integrity of the residential complex or part of it. The Tenants were aware of the work order more than 60 days before the work was undertaken.  The work was carried out at reasonable times in compliance with existing noise by-laws.  The only part of the regulations which would allow for the Board to award a rent abatement to the Tenants is with respect to sect 8 (4)5. which requires the Landlord to provide the Tenant with an update in case there is any significant change in the information provided in the notice.  There is no indication that the Landlord updated the Tenants as to the additional time required to complete the work once it was discovered that the problem was worse than originally thought.  It would therefore be appropriate to award a rent abatement with respect to this issue. 
  Pursuant to section 8(6) of the regulations no abatement shall exceed 25% of the monthly rent of the months for which there was substantial interference except as permitted under section 8(7) of the regulations.  I am not satisfied that the foundation work done by the Landlord meets the criteria listed in section 8(7) of the regulations.  Therefore any rebate awarded would be limited to 25% of the monthly rent for any one month. 
  One of the elements of the repair work that allegedly interfered with the Tenants’ reasonable enjoyment was the absence of a parking spot during the repair period, and the absence of a secondary exit.
  In light of the Landlord’s evidence on the availability of a parking space at the end of the driveway, I find that the Tenants failed to convince me on the balance of probabilities that they were without a parking space for any period of time.
  However, I do find that the noise and possible vibrations from the repairs disturbed the Tenants’ quiet enjoyment of their unit.
   I believe the repairs took place between November 8, 2011 and December 23, 2011.  The Tenants did not claim for compensation for November 2011. It would therefore be appropriate that the rent abatement cover only the period from December 1 to December 23, 2012.  In light of the Tenants’ failure to prove that the repairs caused them to be without a parking space, it would be reasonable to award a rent abatement that is less than the maximum of 25%.  I therefore find that a 20% rent abatement would be more reasonable under the circumstances.  In consideration that the lawful monthly rent is $900.00 and the Tenants’ quiet enjoyment of their unit was disturbed for a period of 23 days at most (3/4 of the month), it would be appropriate to award a rent abatement of $135.00 (3 weeks or 3/4 of the monthly rent of $900.00 X 20% rent abatement).
