Order under Section 30 & 69
Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
  File Number: EAL-22549-12
EAT-22766-12
       
SG (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict DG and PC (the 'Tenants') because they, another occupant of the rental unit or someone they permitted in the residential complex have wilfully or negligently caused undue damage to the premises. The Landlord has also applied for an order requiring the Tenants to compensate the Landlord for the damage. The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenants remained in the unit after the termination date.
  The Tenants applied for an order determining that the Landlord failed to meet the Landlord's maintenance obligations under the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act') or failed to comply with health, safety, housing or maintenance standards.
  These applications were heard in Pembroke on April 16, 2012.  The Landlord, represented by IK, and the Tenants, represented by RO, attended the hearing.  Also in attendance were four witnesses called by the Tenants to testify.
  Preliminary Matters:
  The parties agreed prior to the commencement of the hearing not to exclude the Tenants’ witnesses from the hearing room.
  Issues:
  The Landlord claims the Tenants have damaged an interior door and what the cost is to replace the door; replace and install an exterior door and screen door; supply and install flooring in the living and dining room; supply and install a bathtub and tub surround; repair and paint walls; repair basement stair; replace a wireless doorbell; replace accessories for a central vacuum system; plumbing costs; replace a garage door.  The Landlord is seeking $11,673.82 and termination of the tenancy.
  The Tenants claim the Landlord has not repaired the garage door; stove fan; dripping bathtub taps; basements stairs; driveway.  The Tenants are seeking $4,800.00, approximately 48% of the rent they have paid over the past 12 months.
  Determinations:
  The Landlord provided letters from people who were not present to testify at the hearing.  As such, I give these letters little weight and give more weight to the direct testimony from witnesses that the Landlord’s representative had the opportunity to cross examine.
  Basement Stairs: The parties agree the basement stairs have been repaired and are not pursuing this issue.
  Interior Door: The Tenants dispute that they caused damage to the door.  The Tenants’ witness Michel Lavoie (ML) testified that the door broke while he was a tenant in the unit 5 years before the Tenants moved in due to the misalignment of the door in the door jam.  He repaired it and at the time it would function.  Cross examination did not discredit this testimony.  I find the door was broken before the Tenants moved into the unit.
  Bathtub and Surround:  The Landlord claims that the Tenants painted the bathtub and damaged the tub surround and that it now needs to be replaced.  The Tenants dispute the Landlord’s claim.  (ML) testified that bathtub was painted when he lived there and a second tenant witness, Trevor Moss (TM), testified that he repaired the tub surround because it was falling apart and very old.  I accept the testimony that the bathtub was painted before the Tenants moved in and from the photographs submitted as evidence by the Tenants, it appears that the bathtub and surround are very old and have outlived their useful life.  I find the Tenants are not responsible for the bathtub or surround.
  Exterior Door and Screen Door:  The Tenants’ witness (TM) along with the three other witnesses testified that the does not fit in the opening properly and as a result it would not open or close properly.  (TL) who lived in the home, testified it was like that when he lived there.  The struggle to close the door caused damage over time.  (TM) who has worked for a window and door company for 20 years, testified that he replaced the old door for the Tenants with a new higher quality door than was there previously.  All witnesses testified the screen door was damaged and did not fit properly from the time the Tenants moved into the unit.  In addition, testimony from the Landlord and the Tenants shows that the foundation was repaired in 2009.  I find the issues related to these items had to do with the alignment of the house and that the Tenants replaced the rear door with a similar or better new door at no expense to the Landlord.  I also find the screen door was damaged before the Tenants moved into the unit and that the torn screen is the only damage that was caused after the tenancy commenced.
  Flooring: Photographs and testimony show that the floors are very old and have been in a state of disrepair for a long time.  Notices from the Landlord to enter the unit to perform an inspection introduced as evidence show that the Landlord was in the unit on at least 7 occasions between April 2011 and February 2012.  It would seem reasonable to assume that if the floors were in such a state of disrepair due to the Tenants’ wilful or negligent damage the Landlord would have taken steps to deal with this issue after the inspections or one would have to ask the purpose of the inspections in the first place.  Testimony from (ML) shows that the floors were in a state of disrepair when he lived there, linoleum tiles in the kitchen had nails in places and the substance the Landlord claims is cat litter is actually the ruminants of carpet that was removed a long time ago.  I find the Tenants did not cause wilful or negligent damage to the floors.
  Repair and Paint Walls: When the Tenants moved into the rental unit the Landlord provided them with the tools to paint the interior of the home and 2 gallons of paint to complete the work.  The Tenants undisputed testimony shows that the amount of paint provided was not adequate to finish the work and the Landlord did not provide additional paint.  As a result there are areas of the walls that are not painted and continue to have exposed plaster from repairs.  A photograph shows there is a hole in one wall where the doorknob from a door had broken through the wall over time.  There is also one small area of a wall where there are 10 nails holes in a confined area.  I find the Tenants are responsible for the cost to repair the holes in the wall.  Considering the fact the Tenants performed the labour to paint the walls for the Landlord when they moved in 6 years ago and the Landlord, having been in the rental unit several times over the years has not been concerned about the condition of the walls while the Tenants resided in the unit, I find the request for $5,085.00 to paint and repair the walls to not only be excessive but leads me to question the credibility of the notice and application.
  Wireless Doorbell:  The Landlord testified there was a wireless doorbell when the Tenants moved in and it is now missing.  The Tenants testified there was not a wireless doorbell.  There was no evidence that there was a wireless doorbell and one of the Tenants’ witnesses testified there was no doorbell.  I find there is insufficient evidence to support this claim.
  Central Vacuum:  The Tenants testified and introduced a photograph showing that all of the parts to the central vacuum, which they and a witness claim the vacuum does not work, are in the rental unit.  I find the Tenants have not disposed of these items.
  Plumbing Costs: The Landlord claims that the Tenants caused problems with the plumbing by pouring grease down the drain, clogged the drain with hair and caused a small rag to block the drain.  The invoices submitted by the Landlord make no reference costs related to either grease or hair.  There is one invoice that shows a small rag was in the drain causing a leak.  I find, considering the length of time the Tenants have lived in the unit, the Tenants caused the rag to enter the drain and responsible for the $118.55 cost the Landlord incurred to have the problem repaired.
  Garage Door:  Testimony from the Tenants’ witnesses and photographs of the garage show that the garage is old and out of alignment.  The track the door runs on is detached from the wall and door does not open and close properly.  The Landlord introduced a report from Risk Management Services Inc. and argues there are no safety issues identified regarding the garage.  Although this may be true, the issue is whether the Tenants damaged the door and should pay $904.00 to replace the door as requested by the Landlord, or if the door has not been operating properly and the Landlord has not repaired it for the Tenants.  There is no evidence that the door is damaged and requires replacement.  However, there is evidence the track and operating system are in need of repair and the Landlord has done nothing to address the problem since being informed in writing on November 25, 2011.  I find the Landlord has not repaired the garage door and this has made it difficult for the Tenants to open and close the door.
  Stove Fan:  A photograph of the outside vent shows that there is a hole in the wall above the vent and this hole needs to be repaired.  Considering the fact that the Tenants informed the Landlord in writing on November 25, 2011 that the stove fan is broken and needs to be fixed, I find the Landlord has not repaired the stove fan as required.
  Bath Tub Taps:  The Landlord replaced the seals for the bath tub taps within the past 12 months.  The Tenants complained in writing on November 25, 2011 that they are dripping and the Landlord has not investigated the issue.
  Driveway:  The Landlord acknowledges that the driveway is in need of repair and testified that the work will be done after the ground has thawed.  The Tenants testified that they have damaged their muffler due to the condition of the driveway but had no evidence to show they incurred an expense due to the damage.
  I find the requests for compensation from both applications to be excessive.  I find the issues that the Landlord has demonstrated the Tenants are responsible for which are the screen for the screen door, a hole in the wall where a door opens, the nail holes in the walls and the cost of the plumber offset the issues the Tenants have demonstrated the Landlord has failed to repair including the stove fan, garage door and driveway.  As a result no money is owing to either party.  This decision takes into consideration the costs the parties paid to file the applications with the Board.
  I find the Landlord has not established that the Tenants have wilfully or negligently damaged the rental unit.  The tenancy will not be terminated as requested.
  It is ordered that:
  The Landlord shall repair the driveway.
  The Landlord shall inspect and ensure the stove fan functions properly and the outside hole is sealed.
  The Landlord shall repair the bathroom taps as required.
  The Landlord shall ensure the garage door functions properly.
  The balance of the Landlord's and the Tenants’ applications are dismissed.

File Number: EAL-22253-12
  REASONS
         
Reasons to Order EAL-22253-12 issued on April 20, 2012 by John Nolan.
  MA (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict PS (the 'Tenant') because the Landlord requires possession of the rental unit for the purpose of residential occupation.
  This application was heard in Hawkesbury on April 11, 2012.
  The Landlord and the Tenant attended the hearing.  AC testified on behalf of the Tenant.
    REASONS
  The issue:
  The issue to be decided in this application is whether the Landlord in good faith requires possession of the rental unit for the purpose of residential occupation.
The Landlord’s position:
The Landlord has included an affidavit from her son in the application that states that the son is having personal problems at his present address and that his mother has agreed to let him move into the unit in question until the problem is resolved.
The Landlord explained that her son had lost his job in the fall of 2011 and that the ensuing financial problems have caused a severe strain on his relationship with his partner and their living arrangement since the Landlord’s son is unable to contribute financially.  Therefore the Landlord has offered to help out her son by offering to let him move into the Tenant’s unit.
The Tenant’s position:
Testimony from the Tenant and his witness shows the following:
The Tenant does not believe that the Landlord is acting in good faith since she has been trying to get rid of him for some time.  The Tenant believes that the Landlord has been trying to get rid of him because he has been problematic to her by preventing her from doing things her way to the detriment of his rights. 
The Tenant complained to the Landlord of a water leak on April 8, 2011 that originated in the unit above his unit and that caused damage to the ceiling above his bed as well as damage to the wall and ceiling in his bathroom and to some of his belongings.  The Landlord has still not repaired the damage to his unit.
In the summer 0f 2011, the Landlord was unhappy with the placement of the Tenant’s barbeque beside the house and asked him to move it.  When the Tenant moved it onto the front veranda, the Landlord called the fire chief to have the Tenant remove it.  The fire chief did not oblige the Tenant to move the barbeque off the veranda.   
On June 24, 2011, the Landlord was ordered by the Electrical and Safety Authority to take corrective action in relation to deficiencies found during an inspection.  The Tenant believes that the Landlord suspects that he was behind the complaint to the Electrical Safety Authority, and had given him an unlawful eviction notice in retaliation.  The Landlord gave him an eviction notice on July 5, 2011 that stated “Due to renovations required to bring electrical service up to code as advised by the Electrical Safety Authority, it is necessary that I give notice of sixty days to vacate the above premise where you now reside, making it accessible for the electrical contractor to come in as arranged on Tuesday, September 6, 2011”.  However the Electrical Safety Authority did not require vacant possession for the work to be done, as was confirmed in an August 8, 2011 letter from the Electrical Safety Authority to the Tenant.  The Tenant wrote the Landlord a letter on September 1, 2012, telling her that he did not accept her eviction Notice.  The Landlord called the police on September 8, 2012 to attempt to remove the Tenant from the unit and move his belongings out, but he and his friend managed to convince the police that the eviction notice from the Landlord was not legal.
In her attempt to have the Tenant move, the Landlord refused his rent cheque for August 2011.  When the Tenant had his friend (AC) put the money directly into the Landlord’s account, the Landlord phoned (AC)’s employer to try and have him fired for being a trouble maker.
On October 17, 2012, the Landlord gave the Tenant a rent increase notice.  The rent increase was to take effect on February 1, 2012.  The Tenant refused to pay the rent increase as it was not on a form approved by the Board.  The Landlord filed her application in March 2012 for owner’s own use and the Tenant believes that this is just another attempt to get rid of a troublesome tenant who won’t comply with a Landlord’s every whim.
Analysis
The Landlord was given the opportunity to cross examine the Tenant and his witness with respect to potentially damaging allegations that appeared to show the Landlord was willing to go to great lengths to have the Tenant evicted.  The Landlord declined her opportunity to cross examine the witnesses.  I would have expected the average reasonable individual to attempt to discredit the witnesses’ testimony through cross examination if the allegations were indeed false or inaccurate.
  The Landlord was given the opportunity to respond to the allegations.  She explained that she had not repaired the water damage from the leak that happened in April 2011 because the Tenant would not let in the repairman.  It does not make sense to me that she was able to enter the unit to comply with the Order from the Electrical Safety Authority in September 2011 but still had still not made the repairs from water damage that occurred several months earlier because she was not let into the unit. 
  She explained that she thought she needed vacant possession of the Tenant’s unit to comply with the Work Order from the Electrical Safety Authority because some of the walls would need to be cut to run the wires. However, she did not have any statement from the Electrical Safety Authority requiring vacant possession to justify giving the Tenant an eviction notice for that purpose.  It appears that the Landlord had given the Tenant an eviction notice in July 2011 in retaliation for his possible involvement in the inspection from the Electrical Safety Authority and the subsequent Work Order.
  She explained that she had called (AC)’s employer because he was responsible for the money coming into her account.  Her explanation did not satisfy me as to why she would have called (AC)’s employer.  In view of all the circumstances, I prefer the testimony from the Tenant and his witness that she called (AC)’s employer to have (AC) fired for being a trouble maker.  It appears that the Landlord was trying to solidify her attempt to evict the Tenant whose rent would not have been accepted if it had not been for the intervention of (AC) and his direct deposit into the Landlord’s account.
  The Landlord stated that she disagreed with most of the other allegations which she brushed over by saying that all of theses issues were in the past and that what mattered most was that her son needed to move into the rental unit because of the situation with his finances and relationship with his girl friend with whom he was living.
  I believe on the balance of probabilities that the Landlord has found the Tenant to be a thorn in her side with respect to such issues of the placement of the Barbeque, unattended maintenance issues related to the water leak, the Work Order from the Electrical Safety Authority, and the Tenant’s refusal of a rent increase.  I believe on the balance of probabilities that to Landlord’s failure to evict the Tenant with an illegal notice and police intervention in September 2011, has led her to attempt to evict the Tenant with the only remaining option available to her under the Act.  The timing of her application in March of 2012 on the heels of a rent increase that was to take effect in February 2012 and refused by the Tenant, along with the Landlord’s pattern of behaviour since April 2011 leads me to believe on the balance of probabilities that the Landlord has been trying to get rid of a tenant she sees as troublesome.  I therefore believe on the balance of probabilities that the Landlord does not in good faith require the Tenant’s rental unit for the purpose of residential occupation.

  This application was heard in Ottawa on April 30, 2012.
  The Landlord’s Legal Representative, AK, the Tenant and the Tenant’s Legal Representative, DM attended the hearing.
  In accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006, I canvassed the parties as to whether there are any circumstances in this case that would cause me to consider granting relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act.
  The Tenant’s Legal Representative explained that the Tenant had been involved in a car accident on December 29, 2011 in which he was seriously injured and hospitalized in January and February 2012.  The injury to the Tenant has imposed additional expenses and deprived the Tenant of additional sources of income which has resulted in financial difficulties and the accumulation of arrears of rent.  The people responsible for the accident have accepted liability and compensation is expected.  However, the value of the claim cannot be determined until the Tenant has achieved maximum medical recovery which is impossible to predict.  Claims of this nature usually take one year to eighteen months to resolve.  The Tenant intends to pay his monthly rent on time and would pay the arrears as soon as the settlement arrives, or in the alternative would pay $50.00 per month towards the arrears and costs from April 1, 2013 to September 1, 2013, and $100.00 per month from October 1, 2013 to March of 2014.  The Tenant would greatly appreciate this accommodation to allow him to pay the equivalent of approximately one month’s rent arrears and preserve his tenancy of twelve years during which he has been a good tenant.
  The Landlord’s Legal Representative objected to a payment plan that would require the Landlord to wait for up to two years to be paid the arrears he is owed.  The Landlord was willing to give the Tenant one month to pay his arrears.
  Determinations:
  1.        The Tenant has not paid the total rent he was required to pay for the period from February 1, 2012 to April 30, 2012.  Because of the arrears, the Landlord served a Notice of Termination effective March 20, 2012.
2.        The Landlord collected a rent deposit of $235.00 from the Tenant and this deposit is still being held by the Landlord.
3.        Interest on the rent deposit is owing to the Tenant for the period from June 1, 2000 to March 20, 2012.
4.        The Tenant paid $910.53 after the application was filed.
5.        The amount outstanding to April 30, 2012, inclusive of rent arrears and costs is $893.19.
6.        I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would not be unfair to grant relief from eviction subject to  the condition(s) set out in this order pursuant to subsection 83(1)(a) and 204(1) of the Act.
It is ordered that:
  1.        The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord the amount of $893.19 along with the lawful monthly rent in the following manner.
2.        On or before the first day of each month starting May 1, 2012 and until the arrears and costs are paid in full, the Tenant shall pay to the Landlord the lawful monthly rent.
3.        The Tenant shall pay the balance of the arrears and costs in full immediately upon reception of the compensation settlement related to the automobile accident that occurred on December 29, 2011.
4.        In the event that the compensation settlement is not received by April 2013, the Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $50.00 per month from April 1, 2013 to September 1, 2013 and $100.00 per month from October 1, 2013 to February 1, 2014 towards the arrears and costs.
5.        On or before March 1, 2014, the Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $93.19 towards the balance of the arrears and costs.
6.        In the event that the Tenant fails to make any of the above-said payments in full and on time, the entire balance of the amount set out in this Order shall become due and payable forthwith under this Order. The Landlord shall be entitled to apply to the Board, no later than 30 days after a breach of this order, without notice to the Tenant, for an order terminating the tenancy and evicting the Tenant and for any arrears that have become due after the date of this order, pursuant to Section 78 of the Residential Tenancies Act 2006.

GB (the 'Landlord') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict DF and RF (the 'Tenants') because the Tenants did not pay the rent that the Tenants owe.
  This application was heard in Ottawa on June 11, 2012. the landlord, represented by PLB, and the Tenants, attended the hearing.
  Determinations:
  1.      The Landlord served a notice of termination on the Tenants.  The Tenants vacated the rental unit on June 2, 2012.
  2.      The lawful rent when the Tenants moved into the rental unit was $1,100.00.  The Landlord never served a notice of rent increase as required by the Residential Tenancies Act.  Despite the fact the Landlord wrote into the lease that the rent would increase by $25.00 per month after one year, a landlord must serve a valid notice for the increase to be lawful.  I find the Tenants paid a $25.00 per month unlawful rent increase for 9 months.  The Landlord owes the Tenants $225.00.
  3.      The Residential Tenancy Agreement which was authored by the Landlord at paragraph 8 states “the Landlord acknowledges receipt from the Tenant of the sum of $1,100.00 as prepayment of the last month’s rent”.  The Landlord claims he did not receive a last month rent deposit.  The Tenants testified they paid a last month rent deposit.  Considering the fact that the Landlord allowed the Tenants to move into the unit with an acknowledgement of the payment of a last month rent deposit in the agreement, I find on the balance of probabilities that the Tenants paid an $1,100.00 last month rent deposit.
  4.      The Landlord has not paid the Tenants interest owing on the last month rent deposit.  Interest has been calculated at $32.36.  The Landlord owes the Tenants $32.36.
  5.      The Tenants claim they gave the Landlord a $580.00 personal cheque.  The Landlord testified he returned the cheque to the Tenants, testimony the Tenants dispute.  This order will not include a credit for the $580.00 payment and the Landlord is not to cash this cheque if it is in his possession.
  6.      The Tenants agree they owe the Landlord one month rent for the month of April.  I find the lawful rent for April was $1,100.00.
  7.      The Tenants argue they have been paying for the electricity for air conditioning that they did not control.  They also claim they have been paying for electricity for the laundry room.  I find the Tenants received the services of the air conditioning and the Tenants failed to prove that they have been paying for electricity in the basement.
  8.      The Tenants did not vacate the rental unit until June 2, 2012.  They testified they paid the Landlord for the extra 2 days.  This was included in the $580.00 cheque they gave the Landlord.  Considering the fact the Landlord will be ordered not to cash the cheque, I find the Tenants also owe the Landlord $72.33 for the 2 days in June.
  9.      Considering the fact that the Tenants were in arrears at the time the application was filed with the Board, I find the Tenants are responsible for the $170.00 cost of the application.
  10.   I find the Tenants owe the Landlord $1,084.97.
  It is ordered that:
  1.      The Tenants shall pay to the Landlord $1,084.97 on or before June 20, 2012.
2.      The Landlord has the right, at any time after June 20, 2012, to collect the full amount owing or any balance outstanding under this order.
3.      If the Tenants do not pay the Landlord the full amount owing by June 20, 2012, the Tenants will owe interest.  This will be simple interest calculated from June 21, 2012 at 3.00% annually on the outstanding balance.
4.      The Landlord shall not cash the $580.00 cheque the Tenants gave him.

The Landlord also claimed compensation for each day the Tenant remained in the unit after the termination date.
  This application was heard in Ottawa on June 7, 2012.
  The Landlord’s Legal Representative, GC, the Tenant and the Tenant’s Legal Representative, EC attended the hearing.  RM, JE and AK testified on behalf of the Landlord. BH testified on behalf of the Tenant.
  In accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006, I canvassed the parties as to whether there are any circumstances in this case that would cause me to consider granting relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act.
  The Landlord was willing to give the Tenant a chance to preserve his tenancy if he stopped using racial slurs in the residential complex and was willing to give the Tenant a period of twelve months to pay for the cost of the application.
  Determinations:
  1.      On or about April 24, 2012, the Tenant uttered racial slurs to insult a tenant that he referred to as a “nigger” and this was done in front of other tenants who witnessed the incident in question.
2.      This conduct has substantially interfered with a lawful right, privilege or interest of the Landlord and has substantially interfered with the other tenants' reasonable enjoyment of the residential complex.
3.      The Tenant was given a first Notice of Termination under section 64 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the “Act”). This notice was void because the Tenant corrected the problem within the time period set out in the notice.  Serving a second Notice of Termination was permissible pursuant to Section 68 of the Act.
4.      I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act'), and find that it would not be unfair to grant relief from eviction subject to  the conditions set out in this order pursuant to subsection 83(1)(a) and 204(1) of the Act.
It is ordered that:
  1.      The Tenant shall not utter racial slurs or racially based insults in the residential complex for a period of twelve months from the date of this Order.
2.      The Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $170.00 for the cost of filing the application in the following manner.
3.      On or before the last day of each month from June 2012 to March 2013, the Tenant shall pay to the Landlord $15.00 towards the cost of the application.

  File Number: EAL-24602-12
       
HR and MR the 'Landlords') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict DH and SS (the 'Tenants') because they have used the rental unit or the residential complex in a manner that is inconsistent with use as a residential premises and that has caused or can be expected to cause significant damage; and because they, another occupant of the rental unit or a person the Tenants permitted in the residential complex have seriously impaired the safety of any person. The Landlords also claimed compensation for each day the Tenants remained in the unit after the termination date.
  This application was heard in Ottawa on July 3, 2012.  The Landlords and the Tenants attended the hearing.  The Tenants were represented by MG.
  Determinations:
  1.     The tenants from the upper unit of the triplex were concerned when the smoke alarms went off in the rental complex on the evening of June 15, 2012.  They were particularly concerned by the Tenant DH’s questionable state of sobriety when smoke was emanating from his unit and filling the hallway as well as the Tenant’s apparent lack of concern following the incident. 
2.     The Tenant DH had left food cooking unattended on the stove in the basement unit which caused smoke to set off the smoke detectors in the three unit triplex.  A neighbour’s wife had knocked on the Tenant’s door to check on the smoke.  The Tenant removed the pan from the stove and let the smoke clear out from his opened front door and through the open door to the complex.  There was no evidence of a fire or fire damage and the smoke detector in the Tenants’ unit was found to be functional after the incident.  The neighbouring tenants did not feel enough concern to evacuate their unit or to call the fire department.
3.     In considering that smoke alarms are designed to alert people to attend to a problem before it gets out of hand, such as in situations like this where a pan has been inadvertently left on a heating element, and in considering that the smoke alarm in the Tenant’s unit was functional and not disabled, and that the Tenant DH was the one who attended to the source of the smoke himself when he became aware of the problem, and in considering and that there was no fire or damage, and the neighbouring tenants were not concerned enough to call the fire department or evacuate their unit, I find that the Landlord has failed to convince me on the balance of probabilities that the Tenants seriously impaired the safety of any person, or that they have used the rental unit or the residential complex in a manner that is inconsistent with use as a residential premises and that has caused or can be expected to cause significant damage to the premises.
It is ordered that:
  1.      The Landlords’ application is dismissed.

2.      At the hearing on June 25, 2012 only the Tenant LT attended the hearing.  The Tenants EM and MF opted not to be present or to be legally represented at the hearing.  Prior to the hearing on June 25, 2012, the Tenant LT had the opportunity to meet with Duty Counsel to obtain legal advice.

  REASONS
     
In the matter of:
1023, 201 BELL STREET NORTH

        Between:

  Landlord
        and
          Ningzhi Lou
  Tenant
          Reasons to Order EAL-24780-12 issued on July 27, 2012 by Wayne MacKinnon.
  The Landlord applied for an order requiring the Tenant to pay the rent that he owes.
  This application was heard in Ottawa on July 19, 2012.
  The Landlord’s representatives, Kathy Bartkowski (KB) and Michael Thiele (MT), and the Tenant, and the Tenant’s Counsel, Kathleen Jin (KJ), attended the hearing.
  The Tenant moved into the rental unit on July 1, 2011. At the time of signing the lease agreement, the Landlord’s representative brought to the attention of the Tenant, an addendum to the lease agreement, which was, in fact, notice of a prompt payment promotion. This was a promotion that the Tenant wanted to be a part of.
  The promotion was a separate contract added to the main lease agreement. This contract between the Landlord and the Tenant, promised to credit the Tenant $850.00 for his rental unit (1023) at 201 Bell Street, in Ottawa, ON. The credit was to be applied to the rent of May, 2012, as well as a further credit of $300.00 off for the first month’s rent (July 1, 2011).
  The Tenant, in this case, wanting to be sure that he had all the ingredients for the promotion, specifically asked the office staff if he had followed all of the rules, and paid all of the rental amounts to qualify for the promotion. The staff person checked over all of the Tenant’s information and the Tenant provided her with post dated cheques for each month, except the month of May, 2012 (because that was to be the free month), and the staff person assured him that everything was in place for him to benefit from the promotion.
  The Landlord cashed all of the Tenant’s post dated cheques, as the cheques became due and payable during each month of the tenancy, and, in May, 2012, there was no cheque to cash because the Tenant believed, based both on the assurance of the staff person in the office, and the promotion contract itself, that there was no cheque necessary to cover the month of May, 2012. Nowhere on the promotion contract  is the amount of $905.00 even mentioned. The contract deals throughout, with one amount of rent ($850.00). Only in the more formal lease agreement, do we see the additional amount of $55 for the parking. This is something that should have been brought to the Tenant’s attention by both the Landlord’s representative, and the staff person that assured the Tenant that he was all paid up for the promotion. On May 4, 2012 (a time when the Tenant was supposed to be rent-free for the remainder of the lease agreement) when the Landlord’s representative brought this to the attention of the Tenant (i.e. the payment of the $55.00 for parking), he immediately paid that parking charge.
  Because of the way that this contract is phrased, and lacking any mention of the parking fee, just the rental portion of $850.00 in the contract, and then having the Tenant told, by staff in the office, that he qualifies with the post dated cheques that he provided to the Landlord upon moving in, certainly caused some confusion in the mind of the Tenant, and I fail to see any fairness in this action at all. Further to this, if there is any question or confusion or misunderstanding in any part of any contract, the party that authored the contract is the person that is responsible. In this case that would be the Landlord.
  For all of these reasons I find that the Tenant has paid all the monies, and paid them in advance, that he was supposed to pay, to avail himself of the benefit of that promotion. I also find that the Tenant owes the Landlord no monies, not rent, not parking, not costs, and not any reimbursement of monies benefiting the Tenant as a result of that ambiguous wording set out in that contract.

2012canlii57824:
Order under Sections 31 & 69
Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
  File Number: EAL-24920-12
EAT-24249-12
       
SG and AP (the 'Tenants') applied for an order determining that LD (the 'Landlord'), or the Landlord’s Counsel, harassed, obstructed, coerced, threatened or interfered with them, entered the rental unit illegally and substantially interfered with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit or residential complex by the Tenants or by a member of their household. The Landlord also applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenants because the Tenants did not pay the rent that the Tenants owe.
  These applications were heard together, in Smiths Falls, on July 25, 2012.
  The Tenants, and the Landlord LD, and the Landlord’s Counsel, DGH, attended the hearing.
    Determinations:
  1.      The Tenants have not paid the total rent they were required to pay for the period from May 1, 2012 to July 31, 2012. Because of the arrears, the Landlord served a Notice of Termination effective May 31, 2012. The Landlord filed an application on June 28, 2012 to terminate the tenancy and to collect the arrears of rent
2.      The Tenants had filed an application about tenant rights on May 29, 2012, fully one month before the Landlord filed his application, and the reasons for this application were because the Landlord entered the Tenant’s rental unit illegally, and the landlord and the Landlord’s Counsel had seriously interfered with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit by the Tenants or by members of their household, and had harassed, interfered with and threatened them.  
3.      There was no dispute about the amount of the rental arrears by the Tenants. In a letter from the Landlord’s Counsel to the Tenants, dated June 15, 2012, the Landlord offered the Tenants an abatement of rent in the amount of $2,450.00 (“…meaning you don’t have to pay May and June’s rent…”) as well as moving costs, not to exceed $610.00, if the Tenants were to move by June 30, 2012. The Landlord had already, at the time of making this initial offer, advertised the Tenant’s unit, for rent, in the issue of a local newspaper, issued on June 7, 2012. When asked by the Member, at the hearing on July 25, 2012, if that offer of an abatement of rent was still available as an option, at this late date, and the Landlord’s Counsel responded in the affirmative. What that means is that the only rent left owing is rent for July, 2012 in the amount of $1,215.00, plus $170.00 in costs for the filing fee, for a total amount of rent owing of $1,385.00.
4.      With respect to the Tenants’ application, the Tenant alleges that the Landlord (LD) has entered the rental unit on a few different occasions and then proceeded to describe two illegal entries, in detail.
5.      The Tenant moved into the rental unit on March 1, 2012. Beginning sometime around May 14, 2012, the Tenant brought to the attention of the superintendent that there were bugs/insects of some kind causing bites to the skin of the Tenant and the other members of his household. The Superintendent stated that they were bed bugs and that he too, had an ongoing problem with bed bugs, in his own unit. The Tenant, shortly thereafter, proceeded to a local hospital and saw and spoke with a doctor there who stated that he and his family were being bitten by ‘bed bugs’.
6.      Neither the Superintendent, nor the Landlord appeared ready or willing, to take any action to deal with these bed bugs. The Tenant provided evidence, oral, documentary and photographic, to support his allegations of the presence of bed bugs in the rental unit. The Landlord stated that the Tenant must have brought those bugs with him when he moved into the rental unit. It would seem that the bugs would have made an appearance a little earlier in the tenancy if the Tenant had indeed brought them with him upon moving into the rental unit on March 1, 2012, and also that would not explain the infestation in the super’s unit. Notwithstanding all of that, the Landlord would not take any action to try and rid the unit of bed bugs.
7.      The Landlord had discovered somehow that the Tenant had a criminal record, and had shared this information with some of the other tenants in the rental complex, in a bid to cause friction and problems between the Tenant and his neighbours. The Landlord began to make it clearer that he wanted the Tenant to go, to move out of this complex. Besides the failure to do anything about the bed bugs and, the illegal entries by the Landlord, and also by attempting to entice him to vacate the rental unit with a monetary offer, the Landlord acted somewhat out of character by waiting around the Tenant’s rental unit, and taking pictures of the Tenants and their five children, and also threatening the Tenant, mostly by stating that he would be evicted at any given time.
8.      There are other issues in this tenancy which should have been brought forward in a proper way (relevant and proper applications), such as mushrooms growing in the door way of the rental unit, trenches dug in the back yard which proved a hazard for children playing in the yard, etc.
9.      What was interesting is that neither the Landlord nor his Counsel made any effort to disprove or deny most of the above noted evidence provided by the Tenants. There was practically no dispute on the part of the Landlord at all. Based on all of the disclosed evidence at the hearing, and based on a balance of probabilities, I find that the Landlord or the Landlord's superintendent or the Landlord's agent harassed, threatened and interfered with the Tenants, entered the rental unit illegally and substantially interfered with the reasonable enjoyment of the rental unit or residential complex by the Tenants or by a member of their household.
10.   The Tenant has requested that the Board order the Landlord to pay compensation for toys and other belongings of the children that the Landlord simply buried in the back yard in those trenches that were dug for the kennels. The Landlord did not provide any evidence of those things ever existing or evidence that would provide replacement or repair costs or estimates of same. No monies will be awarded in this instance, as a result of that lack of evidence.
11.   The Tenant had already vacated the rental based on an undertaking from the Courts that he would reside with his surety, and not go to the rental premises, except for a sole trip to the premises to gather together his personal belongings and those of his family and move them out of the rental unit. The Tenant will be able to make that sole trip to pick up his belongings accompanied by a peace officer from the Ontario Provincial Police Force.
  It is ordered that:
  1.      In accordance with the Court undertaking with respect to this Tenant, the Tenant shall be entitled to arrange with the OPP for an escort, to be able to pick up his personal belongings from this rental unit, on Friday, July 27, 2012, between 9:00 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. The Landlord shall refrain from any interference at all in the execution of this arrangement.
2.      The tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenants was terminated as of July 27, 2012.
3.      The Tenants shall pay to the Landlord $1,385.00, which amount represents the amount owing for arrears of rent, and costs. The former amount for May and June, 2012, was waived by the Landlord’s Counsel. 
4.      The Landlord shall pay to the Tenant $1,200.00, which amount represents an abatement of rent for the months of April, May, June and July, 2012, at 25% per month for those four months. This amount was awarded due to the illegal entries by the Landlord, and for his inaction with respect to the issue of the bed bugs in the rental unit.
5.      The Landlord shall also pay to the Tenants $610.00 which is the reasonable out of pocket expenses the Tenants have incurred for moving costs.  
6.      The total amount the Landlord owes to the Tenants is $1,810.00.
7.      The Landlord or the Tenant shall pay any monies owing to one or the other, on or before   August 18, 2012. The Landlord may subtract the arrears payment owing ($1,385.00) from the abatement and moving costs awarded.
8.      If the Landlord does not pay the Tenants the full amount owing by August 18, 2012, he will owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from August 19, 2012 at 3.00% annually on the balance outstanding.
9.      If the unit is not vacated on or before July 27, 2012, then starting July 28, 2012, the Landlord may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
10.   Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlord on or after July 28, 2012.
